questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father due to persistent fever, lower back pain, and a chronic flexed posture of the hip. The child has a history of spinal tuberculosis. On examination, there is inguinal swelling and pain with passive hip extension. A CT scan image of the retroperitoneum (shown) highlights the muscle involved. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a
 
  • The inguinal swelling in the image is caused by the psoas abscess extending into the inguinal canal.
  • The psoas major muscle is the most likely muscle to be involved in this case because it is the muscle that is most affected by psoas abscess.
  • Psoas abscess is most commonly caused by infection from the spine, such as from spine TB.
  • The infection can spread to the psoas major muscle through the intervertebral foramina.

  • This is a classic presentation of a psoas abscess, often seen as a complication of spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease).

  • The psoas muscle originates from the lumbar vertebrae and inserts into the lesser trochanter of the femur.

  • When infected (typically via contiguous spread from spinal TB), the child presents with:

    • Fever

    • Low back pain

    • Flexed hip posture (to relieve tension on the psoas)

    • Inguinal swelling due to the abscess tracking along the psoas sheath

   



Reference-: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery Edition 28 th Page No 1104

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with early satiety and a sense of fullness in the left upper quadrant. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender mass is palpated below the left costal margin, measuring 15 cm in length, and moving inferiorly with inspiration but not descending straight downward in a vertical line. A diagnosis of splenomegaly is made. What is the obstruction that stops the spleen from falling vertically in a patient whose costal border had splenomegaly measuring 15 cm?
questions.solution:
The phrenicocolic ligament (also known as the sustentaculum lienis) stretches between the left colic flexure and the diaphragm, helping to support the inferior aspect of the spleen.

  • In massive splenomegaly, the phrenicocolic ligament physically prevents the spleen from falling vertically downward, causing it to enlarge diagonally or medially.

  • It acts like a "hammock" supporting the spleen inferiorly.

Other options:

  • Tail of pancreas lies in the splenorenal ligament, but doesn’t impede descent.

  • Hilum is where vessels enter/exit; not an external obstructing structure.

  • Lienorenal (splenorenal) ligament connects the spleen to the left kidney and transmits vessels but doesn’t limit vertical descent.

    Clinical pearl
    In clinical examination of splenomegaly, remember that the spleen enlarges diagonally across the abdomen, not vertically downwards, due to support from the phrenicocolic ligament.


  

Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1189

questions.text: Select the joint type shown in the red circle in the image.
questions.solution:
• The red circle shows a Costovertebral joint
  • They are formed by the articulation of articular facets on the head of ribs and costal facets on the bodies of thoracic vertebrae. These joints are a type of plane synovial joint and it allows slight gliding movements, which contribute to the flexibility of the rib cage during respiration. They provide stability to the spine as well.
Other options:

  • Syndesmosis: fibrous joint (e.g., interosseous membrane).

  • Synarthrosis: immovable joint (e.g., sutures in the skull).

  • Synchondrosis: cartilaginous joint with hyaline cartilage (e.g., growth plate).

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 102,103,299

questions.text: Which of the following is a remnant of the Wolffian duct in females?
questions.solution:
• In females, the Wolffian (mesonephric) ducts regress due to the absence of testosterone.

  • Gartner duct cysts are remnants of these ducts, located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

  • Other structures listed are not embryological remnants of the Wolffian duct:

    • Pouch of Douglas: rectouterine peritoneal fold.

    • Uterovesical pouch: peritoneal fold between uterus and bladder.

    • Iliac fossa: an anatomical area in the pelvis, not a ductal remnant.


Clinical Pearl:
Gartner duct cysts may be asymptomatic or cause vaginal wall swelling and are often found incidentally during pelvic exams or imaging.





 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 353

questions.text: The following structure, marked as 'A' will develop into?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Median umbilical ligament

The structure marked ‘A’ in the given diagram of a developing embryo represents the allantois.
The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the fetal urachus and the urachus is a fibrous remnant of the allantois. 

 

Option (B) Medial umbilical ligament is a remnant of obliterated fetal umbilical arteries

(Option C) The ligamentum teres hepatis (round ligament of the liver) represents the obliterated left umbilical vein. 

(Option D) The falciform ligament is a sickle-shaped, broad, and thin fold of peritoneum that attaches the liver to the front body wall and divides the liver into the left lobe and right lobe.



Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page. No- 182, 249.

choices.text: Ipsilateral fine motor activity of the fingers

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the right side of his neck during an altercation. He is hemodynamically stable. MRI of the cervical spine reveals a lesion involving the lateral part of the dorsal column on the right side at the cervical level. Which of the following deficits is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1) Ipsilateral Proprioception in Upper Limb

The given vignette presents a stab wound with an injury to the dorsal column which carries fibers of conscious proprioception, along with sensations of vibration and fine touch.
  • The fibers in the dorsal column are organized somatotopically with the medial fibers carrying sensations from the lower limb through the fasciculus gracilis.
  • Fasciculus cuneatus carries fibers of the upper limb to its respective nucleus and is located laterally.

Other choices:

  • Lower limb proprioception → fasciculus gracilis (not lateral).

  • Fine motor activity of fingers → corticospinal tract (motor pathway).

  • Contralateral proprioception → dorsal column pathways cross at the medulla, not at spinal level.





Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 165- 167.

questions.text: A medical student was yawning during his afternoon anatomy lecture. His jaw was arrested while yawning. Which muscle is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lateral Pterygoid.

Yawning involves a wide opening of the mouth. Opening of the mouth involves active depression (downward movement) and this movement is brought about mainly by the contraction of the lateral pterygoid.

  • In the wide opening of the mouth, this hinge-like movement is followed by gliding of the disc and the head of the mandible in the upper compartment.
  • At the end of this movement, the head comes to lie under the articular tubercle. Thus, in this medical student, the arrest of yawning occurs likely due to failure of the gliding forward of the articular disc by the lateral pterygoid.

Other options:

  • Medial pterygoid: Elevates and protrudes mandible; no attachment to TMJ disc.

  • Masseter: Elevates mandible; attaches to mandibular ramus.

  • Temporalis: Elevates and retracts mandible; inserts on the coronoid process of mandible.







Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 547.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old college student presents to the outpatient clinic with a sore throat for 4 days. On examination, he has inflamed and enlarged palatine tonsils on the right side with associated difficulty swallowing. He also reports sharp pain in the right ear, despite no signs of ear infection on otoscopic examination. Which nerve is responsible for the referred ear pain in this case of tonsillitis?

1. Auricular Branch of X nerve
2. Tympanic Branch of IX nerve
3. VII Nerve
4. V Nerve
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Tympanic Branch of IX nerve

Due to the shared innervation by the glossopharyngeal nerve, the pain of tonsillitis can be referred to the glossopharyngeal nerve which gives sensory supply to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane, the middle ear, the auditory tube, the mastoid antrum, and air cells. 

The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) innervates:

  • Palatine tonsil

  • Posterior third of tongue

  • Pharynx

  • Middle ear (via its tympanic branch, also called Jacobson’s nerve)

  • Referred otalgia (ear pain) in tonsillitis occurs because:

    • The tympanic branch of CN IX supplies the middle ear.

    • Inflammation in the tonsils or pharynx can stimulate CN IX, causing pain perceived in the ear.

Other options:

  • Auricular branch of X (Arnold’s nerve): Ear canal and external ear — involved in cough reflex from ear canal stimulation.

  • CN VII (Facial nerve): Mainly motor to muscles of facial expression; not involved in pharyngeal or tonsillar sensory innervation.

  • CN V (Trigeminal nerve): Sensory to face, oral mucosa, and anterior 2/3 of tongue — not involved in tonsillar pain.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 149.

questions.text:
The marked structure ‘X’ represents a defect in which of the following?

1. Internal Oblique
2. Fascia Transversalis
3. Transversus Abdominis
4. External Oblique
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fascia Transversalis


The structure marked by ‘X’ represents the deep inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the Fascia Transversalis. 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, approximately midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis, and about 1 cm above the inguinal ligament. It is oval, with a roughly vertical long axis. Its size varies between individuals but it is usually 1–2 cm wide in adults and larger in the male. It is related above to the arched lower margin of transversus abdominis and medially to the interfoveolar ligament.

*  Relation of Deep Inguinal Ring: 



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1080.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of lamellar bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Haversian system

  • Lamellar bone is the mature, organized form of bone found in healthy adults.

  • It is characterized by:

    • Regular parallel alignment of collagen fibers

    • Formation of concentric rings (lamellae) around a central canal (Haversian canal)

    • This structural unit is called an osteon or Haversian system, and it provides mechanical strength.

Other options:

  • Bone marrow: Found within medullary cavities; not specific to lamellar bone.

  • Strength and lightness: General bone properties; not a defining histological feature.

  • Trabeculae: Characteristic of spongy (cancellous) bone, not compact lamellar bone.



     

  • Haversian canals = central channels inside osteons, running lengthwise with blood vessels and nerves.

  • Volkmann canals = connecting channels running across osteons, linking Haversian canals to each other and the periosteum.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.88

questions.text: Which muscle type is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Multipennate

The image shows the pectoralis major muscle. The pectoralis major muscle is classified as multipennate, not unipennate. Multipennate muscles have multiple tendons with muscle fibers that branch out diagonally in a feather-like pattern from the central tendon. The pectoralis major has several tendons with muscle fibers extending in different directions, giving it a multipennate arrangement.
 

Other options: -

Option 1: Cruciate: Muscle fibres are arranged in X shape. Ex:- Sternocleidomastoid

Option 3: Parallel: Muscle fibres in these muscle run parallel to the length of muscle. Ex:- Biceps brachi

Option 4: Unipennate: Muscle fibres are arranged on one side of tendon. Ex:- Extensor digitorum

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.112

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a suspicious lesion involving the spongy (penile) urethra. Which lymph nodes are most likely to receive lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Deep inguinal nodes 
 
  • The spongy urethra, also known as the penile urethra, is part of the male urethra that runs within the penis.
  • It is lined with stratified columnar epithelium and receives lymphatic drainage from the deep inguinal nodes.
  • The deep inguinal nodes are located along the femoral vein in the femoral canal and receive lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra, the glans penis, the penile skin, and the scrotum.

  



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1283

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He complains of an urgent need to urinate but is unable to pass urine. On physical examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethra, as well as swelling and bruising of the penis and scrotum. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
• Blood at the urethral meatus and scrotal/penile swelling (butterfly perineal ecchymosis) indicate a rupture of the bulbar urethra.

  • The bulbar urethra lies in the perineum and is vulnerable to injury from straddle trauma (e.g., motorcycle accidents).

  • Urine extravasates into the superficial perineal space, causing swelling of the penis and scrotum.

Other options:

  • Penile urethra rupture usually presents with localized penile swelling but less perineal involvement.

  • Membranous urethra injury is usually associated with pelvic fractures and causes deep pelvic pain, blood at meatus, but less swelling of penis/scrotum.

  • Urinary bladder injury often presents with gross hematuria, inability to void, and lower abdominal pain, often with pelvic fractures.

     

Clinical pearl: In trauma patients with blood at the urethral meatus, do not attempt catheterization until urethral injury is ruled out by retrograde urethrogram.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no: 1520,1540-1

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes surgery for a pancreatic head tumor. During the operation, the common hepatic artery is inadvertently ligated. The surgeon is concerned about the subsequent impairment of blood supply to downstream vessels. Which of the following arteries would most likely have compromised blood flow following ligation of the common hepatic artery?
questions.solution:
• The common hepatic artery is a branch of the celiac trunk and gives rise to:

    • Proper hepatic artery → gives off right gastric artery

    • Gastroduodenal artery → gives off right gastroepiploic artery

  • Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood flow to:

    • Right gastric artery

    • Right gastroepiploic artery

  • The left gastric artery is a direct branch of the celiac trunk (not affected).

  • Short gastric vessels arise from the splenic artery, which is also a direct branch of the celiac trunk and not affected by common hepatic ligation.





 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e74,1464.e75,1168

choices.text: Lower fibres attached to base of sacrum
Upper attachment to transverse process of T12

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of lower back pain after heavy lifting. During the physical examination and imaging, the anatomy of the iliolumbar ligament is reviewed to understand its role in lumbosacral stability. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the iliolumbar ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Upper attachment to transverse process of T12
 

The iliolumbar ligament:

  • Upper fibers attach to the transverse process of L4 and L5 vertebrae, not T12.

  • Lower fibers attach to the iliac crest (not upper fibers — upper fibers attach to L4/L5 transverse processes).

  • It helps stabilize the lumbosacral junction by anchoring lumbar vertebrae to the ilium.

  • Lower fibers do not attach to the base of sacrum; they mainly attach to iliac crest and sometimes to the sacrum but not the base.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1366,1367

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for a routine health check. She has recently started her periods and is concerned about the various bodily changes she is experiencing. The physician explains the role of estrogen in pubertal development. Which of the following is NOT a pubertal alteration that is estrogen-dependent?
questions.solution:
• Estrogen-dependent changes include:

    • Menstruation (due to endometrial proliferation and withdrawal bleeding)

    • Vaginal cornification (estrogen causes maturation and keratinization of vaginal epithelium)

    • Cervical mucus changes (becomes thin and stretchable during ovulation under estrogen influence)

  • Hair growth (pubic and axillary) is androgen-dependent, primarily stimulated by adrenal androgens during adrenarche, not directly by estrogen.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 390,391

questions.text: Except for which of the following, all are involved in transport across the nucleus?
questions.solution:
• Importins: These are nuclear transport receptors that actively shuttle proteins into the nucleus by recognizing nuclear localization signals (NLS).

  • Local signals (meant here as nuclear localization signals, or NLS): Short amino acid sequences that direct proteins to the nucleus.

  • Caveolins: While they are membrane-associated proteins involved in caveolae formation and endocytosis, they may seem unrelated to nuclear transport — but they have been shown in some contexts to translocate to the nucleus under stress conditions (e.g. caveolin-1 nuclear localization reported in some studies).

  • Raf proteins: These are cytoplasmic serine/threonine kinases in the MAPK signaling cascade. They do not translocate into the nucleus themselves; instead, they activate downstream effectors like MEK and ERK, which then enter the nucleus.

 

Reference :https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2882124/

questions.text: A researcher discovered many strands of fibrous proteins that are twisted together into a stable structure and distribute tensile pressures among cells in the tissue while examining the cytoskeleton. Which of the following structures is the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• Intermediate filaments distribute mechanical stress between cells via desmosomes and hemidesmosomes.

  • Microtubules and microfilaments are more dynamic and not primarily responsible for tensile strength.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 843,824

questions.text: A biochemistry researcher notes that glycogen stores are present in both liver and skeletal muscle. However, only one of these tissues can directly release free glucose into the bloodstream. Glycogen is incapable of contributing directly to blood glucose in which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
Glycogen stored in muscle cannot contribute directly to blood glucose because muscle lacks the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is necessary to convert glucose-6-phosphate (produced during glycogen breakdown) into free glucose that can exit the cell and enter the bloodstream.

In contrast, the liver does contain glucose-6-phosphatase and therefore can release free glucose into the blood, helping to maintain blood glucose levels during fasting or between meals.

So, muscle glycogen is used only for local energy needs, especially during exercise, and does not support blood glucose directly

Clinical insight: Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase (e.g., Von Gierke disease) lead to severe fasting hypoglycemia because the liver can't release free glucose.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 435,436

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of nasal congestion, sneezing, and itchy eyes, which worsen at night. His physician notes that a recent complete blood count showed a mild eosinophilia. He is otherwise healthy. Which of the following hormones most likely explains the diurnal variation in his eosinophil levels?
questions.solution:
The diurnal variation (daily fluctuation) in eosinophil count is primarily regulated by cortisol, a glucocorticoid hormone released from the adrenal cortex.

  • Cortisol levels are highest in the early morning and lowest at night.

  • Cortisol has immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory effects — it suppresses eosinophil count in the blood.

  • As a result, eosinophil levels are lowest in the morning (when cortisol is high) and rise at night (when cortisol drops).


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10778409/

questions.text: Which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases is affected by Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: TRK B
 

Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) is a member of the neurotrophin family and plays a crucial role in the survival, development, and plasticity of neurons in the central and peripheral nervous systems.

BDNF exerts its effects primarily through the tyrosine kinase receptor B (TrkB):

  • TrkA binds nerve growth factor (NGF)

  • TrkB binds BDNF and neurotrophin-4 (NT-4/5)

  • TrkC binds neurotrophin-3 (NT-3)

  • TrkD is not a recognized Trk receptor in this context






Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538532/

choices.text: Secreted by proton pump in the lumen
Due to action of acetylcholine at M3 receptors

questions.text: The following statement is not true about gastric acid secretion:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Stimulated by Cholecystokinin
 

  • Gastric acid is secreted by parietal (oxyntic) cells.

  • Acid secretion occurs via the H+/K+ ATPase proton pump located on the luminal membrane of parietal cells.

  • Acetylcholine stimulates acid secretion by acting on M3 receptors on parietal cells.

  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) primarily stimulates the gallbladder and pancreatic enzyme secretion but does not stimulate gastric acid secretion; in fact, it can inhibit it.




GI REGULATORY SUBSTANCES :-



GI SECRETORY SUBSTANCES :-

   

To remember out of all GIT hormones like gastrin , secretin, VIP, CCK-PZ only gastrin is the only one associated with increased HCl Secretion. Remaining hormones decrease HCl secretion.

ACh is part of the parasympathetic nervous system aka rest and digest system, hence increases HCl secretion.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 456,457,458

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract is the primary site of absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacterial fermentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Colon 
 
  • Humans lack the enzymes to degrade the bulk of dietary fibres.
  • Thus these nondigestible carbohydrates pass the upper gastrointestinal tract unaffected and are fermented in the cecum and the large intestine by the anaerobic caecal and colonic microbiota.
  • Fermentation results in production of multiple groups of metabolites of which short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are the major  metabolic by products.
  • Examples of short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) includes-
    • ACETATE
    • PROPIONATE
    • BUTYRATE            
  • SCFA constitute the major anions in the hindgut contents which are effectively absorbed in the large intestine. Thus option 4 – COLON is the answer to this question.
  Maximum absorption of metabolites-  Jejunum > ileum > colon > duodenum except : 
1. Vit B12 & Bile salt - Terminal Ileum
2. SCFA - colon
3. Iron and folate - duodenum 
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 460

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with dyspepsia and delayed gastric emptying. Which of the following hormones decreases stomach motility and gastric emptying in physiological concentrations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cholecystokinin
 

  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) decreases gastric motility and delays gastric emptying to allow better digestion and absorption of fats and proteins in the small intestine.

  • Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and increases gastric motility.

  • Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) mainly stimulates insulin secretion and has minimal effect on gastric motility.

  • Motilin increases gastric motility and initiates migrating motor complexes during fasting.



GI REGULATORY SUBSTANCES :-



GI SECRETORY SUBSTANCES :-



GLIP - GIP and GLP are mainly involved in insulin secretion , hence CCK is a better answer.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 458

questions.text: Where does the maximum water reabsorption in the Gastrointestinal tract occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Jejunum

Maximum water reabsorption in gastrointestinal tract occurs in the PROXIMAL SMALL INTESTINE. Among the given options jejunum is thus the most appropriate answer in this regard.





Maximum absorption of metabolites-  Jejunum > ileum > colon > duodenum except : 
1. Vit B12 & Bile salt - Terminal Ileum
2. SCFA - colon
3. Iron and folate - duodenum 
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 461

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with a genetic disorder. His parents are both healthy but carriers of the disease. Which of the following diseases is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern?
questions.solution:
• Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene.

  • Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder (FGFR3 mutation).

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia is typically autosomal dominant.

  • Huntington’s chorea is autosomal dominant with anticipation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2176, 2177, 3216, 3404.

Learn more about cystic fibrosis in the video below:

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in his big toe. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum uric acid levels. Which of the following metabolic pathways is primarily involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Purine metabolism
 

  • Gout is caused by hyperuricemia, which results from increased breakdown or decreased excretion of purines.

  • Purines are metabolized into uric acid, which can crystallize in joints and cause inflammation.

  • Pyrimidine metabolism does not significantly contribute to uric acid production.

  • Ketone and protein metabolism are not directly involved in gout pathogenesis.



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, self-mutilating behaviors, and signs of hyperuricemia including gout-like arthritis. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency in a key enzyme involved in purine salvage. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most consistent with this clinical picture of Lesch Nyhan Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options: 

  • Xanthine oxidase deficiency causes xanthinuria, not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

  • APRT deficiency leads to 2,8-dihydroxyadenine stones, not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

  • AMP deaminase deficiency is related to muscle metabolism disorders.



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient’s blood sample shows a protein solution that forms a precipitate when heated to about 40-50°C but redissolves upon further heating. Which of the following proteins is most likely responsible for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bence Jones Protein
 

  • Bence Jones proteins are free light chains seen in multiple myeloma. They characteristically precipitate at 40–50°C and then redissolve when heated further to around 60–70°C. This unique thermal precipitation pattern helps in their identification.

  • Cryoglobulins precipitate at cold temperatures below body temperature (below 37°C) and redissolve upon warming, typically not at 40–50°C.

  • Complement and alpha-2-macroglobulins do not have this characteristic reversible precipitation with temperature changes.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 609.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a genetics clinic for evaluation after experiencing two consecutive first-trimester miscarriages. Her physician suspects a possible chromosomal abnormality and recommends karyotyping as part of her work-up. The laboratory technician discusses various staining techniques used in chromosome banding during karyotype analysis. Which of the following is NOT a recognized chromosome banding technique used in karyotyping?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: S-Banding

Study of chromosome number and structure by staining the dividing cells with certain dyes and then examining them under microscope for cytogenetic analysis is called chromosome banding.

  • G-Banding (Giemsa banding) is the most commonly used technique, revealing characteristic light and dark bands on chromosomes.

  • C-Banding stains the constitutive heterochromatin, particularly centromeric regions.

  • R-Banding (reverse banding) is the reverse of G-banding and highlights regions that stain lightly with Giemsa.

  • S-Banding is not a recognized or standard technique in cytogenetics.


Various types of chromosome banding techniques are-



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 164.

choices.text: With ageing, the length of the telomere shortens gradually

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding telomere and telomerase:
questions.solution:
• Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation.

  • Telomerase is an enzyme that helps maintain telomere length by adding repetitive sequences, especially in stem cells and cancer cells.

  • Option A: Incorrect – Telomeres are non-coding; they do not code for proteins.

  • Option B: Incorrect – In cancer, telomerase activity is often upregulated, allowing cells to divide indefinitely.

  • Option C: Correct – As cells divide over time, telomeres shorten, contributing to cellular aging.

  • Option D: Incorrect – Telomerase prevents shortening of telomeres, not promotes it.



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 355.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 303, 304.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man of Mediterranean descent presents to the emergency department with fatigue, dark-colored urine, and jaundice. He recently started taking primaquine for malaria prophylaxis. On examination, he is pale and mildly icteric. Laboratory tests reveal anemia with elevated reticulocyte count and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear shows "bite cells" and Heinz bodies. He is diagnosed with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Which of the following metabolic pathways is most closely associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
• G6PD is a key enzyme in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway.

  • This pathway generates NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining glutathione in its reduced form. Reduced glutathione protects red blood cells from oxidative damage.

  • In G6PD deficiency, oxidative stress (e.g., from drugs like primaquine) leads to red cell hemolysis due to inability to neutralize free radicals.

  • Kreb's cycle, glycolysis, and gluconeogenesis are unrelated to this oxidative defense mechanism in RBCs.



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 157, 172, 175, 182.
Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 782, 784.

questions.text: A 30-year-old laboratory technician is brought to the emergency department after being accidentally exposed to a chemical during an experiment. He is confused, hypotensive, and has metabolic acidosis. Arterial blood gas shows high lactate levels. The attending physician suspects mitochondrial poisoning due to inhibition of the electron transport chain (ETC), specifically at complex IV. Which of the following agents is known to inhibit Complex IV of the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Cyanide is an inhibitor of cytochrome complex IV. 

Trick- Inhibitors of complex IV end with -IDE Eg- hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide, sodium azide. 
 

  • Cyanide inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, preventing electron transfer to oxygen, halting ATP production, and leading to lactic acidosis.

  • Carbon dioxide is not an ETC inhibitor.

  • Oligomycin inhibits ATP synthase (Complex V).

  • Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II).

    See the table below: 

 
        

Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 123, 145, 472.

questions.text: A 25-year-old research scientist is studying how DNA is tightly packed within the nucleus to fit inside cells. Which of the following proteins plays a primary role in the packing of DNA into chromatin?
questions.solution:
• Histones are small, positively charged proteins around which DNA winds to form nucleosomes, the fundamental units of chromatin structure. This wrapping helps pack DNA efficiently inside the cell nucleus. 

  • DNA is negatively charged due to its phosphate backbone, and histones, being rich in lysine and arginine, neutralize this charge, allowing tight coiling.

  • Several types of histones (H2A, H2B, H3, and H4) form the nucleosome core, and linker histone H1 helps further compact the chromatin.

  • Glycoproteins are proteins with carbohydrate groups, typically involved in cell signaling or structure, but not DNA packaging.

  • Helicases are enzymes that unwind DNA strands during replication and transcription, not involved in DNA packing.

  • Chaperones assist in protein folding and assembly but do not directly pack DNA.



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 107, 339, 342, 343.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman’s genetic testing reveals a mutation in one of her genes where a codon that normally codes for an amino acid has changed to a stop codon, leading to premature termination of the protein. What kind of mutation is this?
questions.solution:
• A nonsense mutation is a point mutation in which a codon that originally codes for an amino acid is changed to a stop codon (UAA, UAG, or UGA). This causes premature termination of protein synthesis, leading to a truncated, usually nonfunctional protein.

  • A missense mutation results in a codon change that codes for a different amino acid but does not create a stop codon.

  • A silent mutation changes the DNA sequence without altering the amino acid sequence, due to the redundancy of the genetic code.

  • A frameshift mutation involves insertion or deletion of nucleotides that are not in multiples of three, causing a shift in the reading frame and altering downstream amino acids.


Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 267, 268.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding vitamin K is true?

1. It acts as an anticoagulant
2. Prolonged use of antimicrobials can lead to its deficiency
3. The recommended dietary allowance is 15–20 mg
4. All of the above
questions.solution:
Vit K is a Fat soluble vitamin which is responsible for synthesis of Clotting factors 2,7,9,10. It is synthesized within the body by the gut flora. Antimicrobials can kill the good flora along with the bad bacteria and can their prolonged use can cause Vit K deficiency.

  • Anticoagulant:

    • False. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors (e.g., Factors II, VII, IX, and X). It actually supports blood coagulation, not anticoagulation.

  • Prolong use of antimicrobial leads to deficiency:

    • True. Antimicrobials can disrupt gut bacteria, which produce vitamin K, leading to a deficiency over time.

  • Dietary allowance is 15-20 mg:

    • False. The recommended daily allowance (RDA) for vitamin K is much lower, typically 90-120 µg (micrograms) for adults, depending on age and gender.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 532.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent episodes of muscle cramps, fatigue, and dark-colored urine following strenuous exercise. He reports that the symptoms improve with rest. A forearm exercise test shows a flat lactate curve, and urinalysis reveals myoglobinuria. Based on clinical features and investigations, he is diagnosed with McArdle’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease type V). Which of the following enzymes is deficient in McArdle's disease?
questions.solution:
McArdle's disease, also known as type V glycogen disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of myophosphorylase- muscle glycogen phosphorylase. 

Option A- Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency results in Hers disease-type VI glycogen storage disease.

Option C- Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase results in Von Gierke Disease- Type I glycogen storage disease.

Option D- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency results in hemolytic anemia with characteristic bite cells on peripheral smear. 



Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A patient presented with hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin and elevated LDH levels. Peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is related to such a condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria, elevated unconjugated bilirubin, and LDH with peripheral smear showing schistocytes are suggestive of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). 
 

These findings are characteristic of intravascular hemolysis, and the presence of schistocytes specifically points toward microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA).

Causes of MAHA include:

  • Prosthetic cardiac valves (mechanical hemolysis)

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)

  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

  • Severe hypertension, preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome

Prosthetic cardiac valves can cause mechanical fragmentation of RBCs, leading to schistocytes and a picture of MAHA.

Other options: 

  • A. Normal to high serum ferritin — Seen in PNH, but PNH typically shows normocytes or occasional spherocytes, not schistocytes.

  • B. Splenomegaly — Seen in extravascular hemolysis (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis, thalassemia), not MAHA.

  • C. Raised HbF — Seen in thalassemia, sickle cell anemia — also not MAHA.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 647, 650.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 785, 786.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman suddenly develops an excruciating headache described as "the worst headache of my life." She also has neck stiffness and nausea. Rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm most commonly results in:
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage is seen due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm.  Clinically it presents with sudden onset thunder clap headache. It maybe associated with seizures, unresponsiveness and vomiting. 

The imaging modality of choice for suspected SAH is NC-CT brain which will show hyperdense blood in basal cisterns. This should be followed by a CT Angiography to localize the site of aneurysm which appears as round contrast filled outpouching. 

Treatment is by doing craniotomy with clipping or endovascular coil embolization. 

Option B- Subdural hemorrhage occurs due to rupture of bridging cortical veins. 

Option C- Epidural hemorrhage occurs due to injury to branches of middle meningeal artery from fracture of underlying bone. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1258, 1259.

Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 335, 652, 653.

questions.text: A 55 years old male presented with complaints of weakness, pallor, weight loss and a dragging sensation in the abdomen. Per abdomen examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Blood pictures showed marked leucoytosis and raised platelet count. Peripheral smear showed myelocytes and metamyelocytes. The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following translocation would be seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
• The clinical picture with massive splenomegaly, leukocytosis, raised platelets, and a peripheral smear showing myelocytes and metamyelocytes (a “left shift”) is classic for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

  • CML is characterized by the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from the t(9;22)(q34;q11) translocation. This translocation creates the BCR-ABL fusion gene, encoding a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that drives uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells.

Option (1)- 8;14 translocation is seen in Burkitt Lymphoma. 

Option (2)- 8;21 translocation is seen in AML M2

Option (4)- 15;17 translocation is seen in AML M3 (APML)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 601, 602, 617-624.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 826.

questions.text: A young male presented with infertility. Semen analysis showed azoospermia. Testicular biospy was done, the image of which is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Sertoli cell-only syndrome (also called germ cell aplasia) is characterized by seminiferous tubules that contain only Sertoli cells without any germ cells, leading to azoospermia and infertility.

  • Orchitis usually shows inflammatory infiltrates and damage to the seminiferous tubules, not absence of germ cells alone.

  • Testicular atrophy involves shrinkage and fibrosis but may still have some germ cells.

  • Carcinoma of the testis would show malignant germ cells, not just Sertoli cells.

        
        Sertoli cell-only syndrome (Del Castillo syndrome)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 974.
Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 241, 242.

questions.text: A 28-year-old previously healthy man dies suddenly after severe COVID-19 infection. An autopsy of his lungs is performed. Which of the following is the most characteristic histopathological finding in the lungs of patients who die from severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
• Severe COVID-19 infection typically causes Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD), which is the histological hallmark of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

  • The key microscopic feature of DAD is the formation of hyaline membranes—these are thick fibrin-rich layers lining the alveoli, resulting from leakage of plasma proteins and fibrin deposition due to alveolar epithelial injury.

  • This disrupts normal gas exchange, leading to severe hypoxia.

  • While pulmonary edema (fluid accumulation) is common in ARDS, it is not as specific as hyaline membranes.

  • Hemorrhagic lung is not a primary feature of COVID-19 lung pathology.

  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages indicate previous bleeding (e.g., heart failure), not a hallmark of COVID-19 lung injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1508, 1509, 2225-2227.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was subjected to lumbar puncture. Gross appearance of CSF specimen is shown in the first image. CSF findings were low sugar, raised protein and mononuclear leucocytosis. Most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with CSF findings of cobweb like clot and slide showing lymphocytic predominance goes in favour of tuberculous meningitis. 

See the table below differentiating between various types of meningitis: 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1100, 1102-1106.

questions.text: A young female developed a slow growing mass in the middle anterior part of the neck. After few months, she had enlargement of cervical lymph nodes on both the sides. She was subjected to biopsy and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is NOT the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with histopathological finding of Orphan Annie Eye nuclei goes in favor of papillary cancer of thyroid. 

Option A- Papillary Ca of thyroid shows a characteristic appearance of nucleus known as Orphan Annie Eye due to preinucleolar clearing. 

Option B- It carries an excellent prognosis among the thyroid cancers.

Option C- It can be diagnosed on FNAC unlike follicular carcinoma. It can be diagnosed on FNAC just on the basis of its nuclear features. 

Option D- It commonly spreads via lymphatics. Lungs are the most common site for distant metastasis for papillary Ca of thyroid. 

Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei are a classic histopathological feature seen in Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC).

  • They are nuclei with cleared-out or empty-appearing chromatin, giving them a “ground-glass” or “empty” look under the microscope.

  • The nuclear membrane appears clear and well-defined, and the chromatin is dispersed, which makes the nucleus look empty or “optically clear.”

  • This gives the appearance similar to the eyes of the comic strip character “Little Orphan Annie” — hence the name.

    Remember the mnemonic: 

    “P’s of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma”

  • P — Papillae (branching finger-like structures)

  • P — Pseudoinclusions (intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions)

  • P — Psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications)

  • P — Powdery chromatin (clear, ground-glass nuclei aka Orphan Annie nuclei)

  • P — Palisading nuclei (aligned nuclei along the papillae)

  • P — Propagation via lymphatics (lymphatic spread to cervical nodes)





Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 817-819.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1087-1089.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B syndrome also known as MEN 3 occurs due to mutation of RET proto oncogene on chromosome 10. 

The associated conditions are-

Medullary Ca of thyroid, Pheochromocytoma, Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, Medullated corneal nerve fibers and megacolon 



Mnemonic: 
MEN Type Mnemonic Key Features
MEN 1 "3 P’s" Parathyroid adenoma Pituitary tumors (e.g., prolactinoma) Pancreatic tumors (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma)
MEN 2A "2 P’s + 1 M" Parathyroid adenoma Pheochromocytoma Medullary thyroid carcinoma
MEN 2B "1 P + 2 M's" Pheochromocytoma Medullary thyroid carcinoma Mucosal neuromas (also marfanoid habitus)

Genes involved: 

  • MEN 1 – Mutation in MEN1 gene (encodes menin)

  • MEN 2A and 2B – Mutation in RET proto-oncogene


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2983, 2988-2990.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cellular swelling
 
  • Cellular swelling is not a feature of apoptosis but rather a characteristic of necrosis.
  • Apoptosis is characterized by nuclear condensation, intact cell membrane, cytoplasmic eosinophilia, and the absence of cellular swelling.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter due to progressive memory loss over the past two years. She frequently forgets names, misplaces items, and has difficulty performing familiar tasks like cooking. On examination, she is alert but oriented only to person. Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score is 18/30. MRI of the brain shows diffuse cortical atrophy, especially in the hippocampus and temporal lobes. She is diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease. A post-mortem brain biopsy reveals neurofibrillary tangles and eosinophilic, rod-like inclusions in the hippocampus. Which of the following inclusion bodies are most likely seen in this patient’s brain tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hirano bodies
 
  • Hirano bodies are intracellular inclusion bodies typically observed in the neurons of individuals with Alzheimer's disease.
  • Hirano bodies are considered to be a hallmark pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease.
  • In contrast, Buschino bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes, and Lewy bodies and Lafora bodies are associated with other neurodegenerative disorders.

IMPORTANT INCLUSION BODIES



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1275.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not lead to the renal pathology is given in the figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diabetes mellitus
 
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the kidney refers to multiple petechial hemorrhages on the renal surface.
  • Conditions associated with this pathology:
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to platelet aggregation and microthrombi formation in renal microvasculature.
    • Malignant hypertension: Severe hypertension leading to arteriolar damage and fibrinoid necrosis in renal arterioles.
    • Infective endocarditis: Infection of heart valves leading to embolic infarctions in the kidney.
  • Diabetes mellitus does not typically cause the flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.

  • Cause: Severe hypertension leads to fibrinoid necrosis of small arterioles and arteriolar rupture causing multiple tiny cortical hemorrhages.

  • Pathophysiology:

    • High pressure damages renal arterioles → endothelial injury → fibrinoid necrosis.

    • Leakage of blood causes tiny hemorrhages scattered across the renal cortex.

    • These hemorrhages look like red pinpoint spots — “flea bites.”

  • Microscopic findings:

    • Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries.

    • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (“onion-skin” appearance).

    • Ischemic changes in renal parenchyma due to vessel narrowing.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a known history of chronic Hepatitis B infection presents with swelling of his legs and frothy urine for the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals pitting edema and mild hypertension. Urinalysis shows heavy proteinuria. A kidney biopsy is performed, and light microscopy reveals thickened glomerular basement membranes with a characteristic “spike and dome” appearance on electron microscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has Hepatitis B infection and presents with nephrotic syndrome (leg swelling, frothy urine, proteinuria).

  • The kidney biopsy shows spike and dome pattern on electron microscopy, which is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

  • Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and can be secondary to infections such as Hepatitis B, malignancies, and autoimmune diseases.

  • The “spikes” represent projections of the glomerular basement membrane between immune deposits (“domes”) located on the subepithelial side.

Other options:

  • Minimal change disease usually occurs in children and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy.

  • FSGS shows segmental sclerosis in some glomeruli.

  • RPGN is characterized by crescent formation and rapid renal function decline, not the spike and dome pattern.





Quick Summary of Key Patterns:
 

  • Spike and dome

    • Seen in membranous nephropathy.

    • Spikes = basement membrane projections between immune deposits (domes).

  • Tram-track

    • Seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN).

    • Due to splitting of GBM by mesangial cell interposition, causing double contour.

  • Starry sky

    • Seen in post-streptococcal GN (and other immune complex GN).

    • Granular immune deposits scattered like stars on immunofluorescence.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with swelling of the legs, decreased urine output, and fatigue. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. Urine microscopy shows casts. Which type of urinary cast is most likely to be present in this patient with renal parenchymal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fine granular cast
 
  • Urinary casts are cylindrical structures formed within the renal tubules and are composed of different materials.
  • In renal parenchymal disease, such as glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis, the casts seen in the urine can provide diagnostic clues.
  • Fine granular casts are composed of finely granular material and can be seen in various conditions, including renal parenchymal disease.
* Other options:
  • Coarse granular casts are formed by the precipitation of cellular debris and are typically seen in renal tubular injury.
  • Hyaline casts are transparent and composed of protein and can be found in both normal and pathological conditions.
  • Epithelial casts contain desquamated renal tubular epithelial cells and can indicate severe tubular injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2304.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with multiple facial papules, oral mucosal papillomas, and a history of thyroid and breast tumors. Genetic testing is considered to confirm the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome. Cowden syndrome is associated with which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PTEN
 
  • Cowden syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of developing certain cancers.
  • It is caused by mutations in the PTEN (Phosphatase and Tensin Homolog) gene.




Pathogenesis of Cowden syndrome


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and night sweats. A lymph node biopsy is done, and the pathology report mentions the presence of L and H cells. L and H cells are characteristic of which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lymphocyte predominance

L and H Cells also known as popcorn cells are seen in NLPHL i.e. Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 613.

questions.text: A 30 years old woman with dyspnea, cough, sputum production and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was a non-smoker and alcoholic. The lung autopsy is portrayed. Which of the following conditions was most likely associated with the woman's death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2)   \(\alpha~\)-1 antitrypsin deficiency
 
  • The Gross specimen suggest emphysematous lungs, it is a chronic lung disease that results in damage to alveoli, the small air sacs in the lungs- pan acinar emphysema.
  • When damaged, alveoli lose their flexibility and cannot feed enough oxygen into the bloodstream.
  • Emphysema is typically caused by long-term exposure to cigarette smoke, as well as environmental pollutants like car exhaust. Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein produced in the liver that helps protect the lungs from damage caused by inflammation.
  • Individuals with emphysema are often low on AAT, leaving their lungs and alveoli vulnerable to the effects of smoking, air pollutants, and other irritants. Though is can be present without active smoking also.
  • Without the protection of AAT, the lung tissue gradually becomes damaged and scarred, leading to difficulty breathing, coughing, and a decreased quality of life.
Other options: 
  • Cystic fibrosis causes bronchiectasis and mucus plugging, mostly affecting upper lobes.

  • Mutation in dynein arm is seen in primary ciliary dyskinesia (Kartagener syndrome), which also causes bronchiectasis but often with situs inversus and infertility; this was not mentioned.

  • Antibodies against Type 4 collagen are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, not bronchiectasis.Cystic fibrosis causes bronchiectasis and mucus plugging, mostly affecting upper lobes.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic for follow-up after a deep cut on his forearm that was sutured 3 months ago. The wound has completely healed with a scar. The doctor explains that the scar tissue mainly consists of which type of collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Type 1
 

The main collagen type in a completely healed scar mark is 1. Type 1 collagen

During wound healing, initially type 3 collagen is laid down to form granulation tissue. Over time, this is replaced by type 1 collagen, which is stronger and forms the bulk of mature scar tissue.

  • Type 1 collagen is the main collagen in completely healed scars, skin, tendon, and bone.

  • Type 2 collagen is mainly found in cartilage.

  • Type 3 collagen is found in early granulation tissue and reticular fibers.

  • Type 4 collagen is a major component of basement membranes.

* [Extra Edge]: Type of Collagen 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 23.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with fatigue, dizziness, and claudication of both upper limbs. On examination, pulses in both arms are weak or absent. Blood pressure is low in the arms but higher in the legs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Takayasu Arteritis
 
  • Takayasu Arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects large vessels, including the aorta and its major branches.
  • It commonly affects young females and leads to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysmal dilation of affected vessels.
  • The involvement of the subclavian arteries can cause upper limb pulselessness, known as "pulseless disease."
  • Other features of Takayasu Arteritis include systemic symptoms, such as fever and fatigue, hand claudications, and symptoms related to the affected organs or regions.
Other options: 

Giant cell arteritis:
Typically occurs in adults over 50 years old, primarily affects the temporal arteries and other branches of the carotid artery, causing headache and visual symptoms, but rarely causes pulselessness in the upper limbs.

Polyarteritis nodosa:
A necrotizing vasculitis of medium-sized arteries that can cause systemic symptoms but usually does not present with pulselessness or blood pressure discrepancies between limbs.

Coarctation of the aorta:
A congenital narrowing of the aorta usually distal to the left subclavian artery, leading to hypertension in upper limbs and weaker pulses in lower limbs, not bilateral upper limb pulselessness.


VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: Granulomatous pathology is linked to all of the following conditions, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polyarteritis Nodosa (Classic PAN)
 
  • Granulomatous pathology is not typically associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).
  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries and does not involve small vessels.
  • It is characterized by transmural inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and aneurysmal formation in affected arteries.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis, Takayasu arteritis, and giant cell arteritis are examples of vasculitides that can exhibit granulomatous inflammation.
  • In Wegener's granulomatosis, necrotizing granulomas involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels are typically seen.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with migrating arthritis involving large joints like knees and ankles. She also complains of palpitations and is found to have a pansystolic murmur on cardiac exam. Echocardiography shows mitral regurgitation. Which of the following would most likely be seen on biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff body
 
  • Upon performing a cardiac catheterization, an endomyocardial biopsy revealed the presence of an Aschoff's body in the endocardium, confirming a clinical suspicion of active carditis.
  • Aschoff bodies are nodules that are discovered in the hearts of rheumatic fever patients. They are a defining feature of rheumatic heart disease and are caused by inflammation in the heart muscle.

Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Other options: 

  • Granuloma annulare:
    A benign skin condition with granulomatous inflammation in the dermis, unrelated to cardiac or joint symptoms.

  • Granulomatous vasculitis:
    Seen in diseases like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s), which typically involves respiratory tract and kidneys, not mitral regurgitation or migrating arthritis.

  • Epithelioid granuloma:
    Seen in tuberculosis or sarcoidosis, but not characteristic of rheumatic heart disease.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A patient with high cholesterol levels is started on a hypolipidemic drug that lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting PCSK-9. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Rosuvastatin: A statin that inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol synthesis in the liver.

  • Clofibrate: A fibrate that primarily lowers triglycerides by activating PPAR-alpha.

  • Evolocumab: A monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK-9, preventing degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing LDL clearance from the blood.

  • Ezetimibe: Inhibits intestinal absorption of cholesterol.


Overview of action of Hypolipidemic drugs:



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 613-615.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man being treated for pulmonary tuberculosis continues to have persistent symptoms despite completing the standard 6-month course of therapy. He is diagnosed with MDR-TB. MDR-TB is defined as resistance to:
questions.solution:
MDR-TB is defined as Mycobacterium tuberculosis resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most potent first-line anti-TB drugs. Resistance to additional drugs like fluoroquinolones or aminoglycosides (kanamycin) defines extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB).

  • Resistance only to isoniazid and rifampicin = MDR-TB

  • Additional resistance to fluoroquinolones and second-line injectable drugs = XDR-TB


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 961, 1359, 1372, 1376.

questions.text:
A 50 years old male who was recently diagnosed as pulmonary TB, was started on ATT. Later on, he presented with the complaints of tingling and numbness over fingers. He is also a chronic alcoholic. This patient should be managed by starting: 
1. Vitamin B1 
2. Vitamin B3
3. Vitamin B6 
4. Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
Isoniazid, a key drug in antitubercular therapy, can cause peripheral neuropathy by interfering with Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) metabolism. Chronic alcoholism also predisposes to Vitamin B6 deficiency. Vitamin B6 supplementation is essential to prevent and treat isoniazid-induced neuropathy.

Management of Isoniazid-Induced Peripheral Neuropathy

  • Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) Supplementation:

    • Dose: 25 to 50 mg orally once daily

    • Given prophylactically to patients at risk (e.g., chronic alcoholics, diabetics, malnourished) or therapeutically once neuropathy symptoms develop.

  • Additional Management:

    • Continue antitubercular therapy without interruption if possible.

    • Monitor for symptom improvement after starting pyridoxine.

    • Address other causes of neuropathy (e.g., control alcoholism, nutritional support).

  • Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency causes Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome but is not directly linked to isoniazid toxicity.

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency causes pellagra.

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy but is not typically caused by isoniazid.





Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 775, 2526.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted for acute exacerbation. He is started on intravenous theophylline as part of his management. Within a few hours, the patient develops increased urine output (diuresis). He denies any changes in fluid intake. Vitals are stable, and there is no evidence of volume overload or diuretic use. Which receptor is most likely responsible for this diuretic action of theophylline?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is not due to its bronchodilatory mechanism, but rather due to antagonism of adenosine A1 receptors in the kidney.

  • Adenosine A1 receptor blockade leads to decreased reabsorption of sodium and water in the proximal tubule and collecting duct, causing diuresis.

  • This is a non-selective action of theophylline and contributes to side effects such as increased urination.


Other options: 

  • Phosphodiesterase inhibition is how theophylline causes bronchodilation (by increasing cAMP), not diuresis.

  • Beta-1 adrenergic receptors are involved in cardiac stimulation and renin release, not directly in theophylline-induced diuresis.

  • Beta-2 adrenergic receptors mediate smooth muscle relaxation, especially in airways — again, unrelated to renal diuresis here.




Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 733-735.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the Emergency Department after reportedly ingesting a large number of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) tablets in a suicide attempt. She is confused and has dry mouth, excessive sweating, postural hypotension, and urinary retention. On cardiac monitoring, her ECG shows a wide QRS complex. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in managing this patient’s cardiac toxicity?
questions.solution:
In TCA overdose, cardiac toxicity results from blockade of fast sodium channels, causing a wide QRS complex and risk of arrhythmias.

Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice because it narrows the QRS complex by alkalinizing the serum and increasing sodium concentration, helping to overcome the sodium channel blockade.
 

Other management points include:

  • Supportive care with airway protection and fluids for hypotension.

  • Avoid antiarrhythmics like lidocaine and drugs that prolong QRS or QT interval.

  • DC cardioversion is not the first-line treatment for TCA-induced arrhythmias unless there is ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

  • Avoid adenosine as it is ineffective for TCA toxicity-related arrhythmias.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 62, 158, 271, 273, 276.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1924, 3587.

questions.text: A 24-year-old college student presents with a non-productive cough, low-grade fever, malaise, and headache for 5 days. His chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates, but physical examination shows minimal findings. He is diagnosed with atypical pneumonia, likely caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. He is started on empirical therapy. Which of the following antibiotics is Mycoplasma pneumoniae inherently resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftriaxone
 
  • Like all microorganisms that lack cell wall, M. pneumoniae is intrinsically resistant to beta-lactams and to all antimicrobials targeting the cell wall, such as glycopeptides and Fosfomycin.  Ceftriaxone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin and hence, a beta lactam and mycoplasma would be resitant to ceftriazxone. 
  • M. pneumoniae is also resistant to polymixins, sulfonamides, trimethoprim, rifampicin and linezolid.
  • Antibiotics with potential activity against M. pneumoniae that are used in clinical practice include macrolides, lincosamides, streptogramin combinations and ketolides (MLSK), tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones.
Active Drugs Against Mycoplasma:
 

  • Doxycycline (tetracycline class): Inhibits protein synthesis.

  • Azithromycin (macrolide): Inhibits 50S ribosomal subunit.

  • Fluoroquinolones: Inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted for treatment of pneumonia. He is started on intravenous penicillin G. After 48 hours, the patient's condition fails to improve, and cultures reveal a strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Laboratory analysis confirms that the bacteria exhibit resistance to penicillin. What amongst the following is not the mechanism of resistance to penicillin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Alteration in 50S ribosome structure


Penicillin and other β-lactam antibiotics act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis through binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs). Bacteria may develop resistance to penicillin through:

  • Altered PBPs (e.g., MRSA): Lowers affinity for penicillin.

  • Drug efflux pumps: Actively expel the drug from the bacterial cell.

  • β-lactamase production: Enzymatically breaks down the β-lactam ring structure, inactivating the drug.

However:

  • Alteration in the 50S ribosome is a mechanism of resistance to protein synthesis inhibitors like macrolides, chloramphenicol, and clindamycin — not penicillin.


                Mechanism of antibiotic resistance

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic liver disease develops a urinary tract infection. The physician considers starting a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is least appropriate for use in patients with liver disease due to its hepatotoxicity risk?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pefloxacin
 
  • Pefloxacin is contraindicated in liver disease because it is metabolized in the liver and can cause function to decrease further, causing serious health issues.
  • This includes increased levels of toxicity and a risk of liver failure. Taking Pefloxacin in this instance can increase the likelihood of serious adverse reactions and, in some cases, death.
  • Moxifloxacin & Pefloxacin are the FQs metabolised in Liver (MoPed by Liver)
  • Other fluoroquinolones like levofloxacin, ofloxacin, and lomefloxacin have a safer hepatic profile and are preferred in such cases.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is started on an antibiotic for a severe bacterial infection. Which of the following antibiotics is not primarily bacteriostatic but rather bactericidal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vancomycin

*Mechanism of Action:
  • Vancomycin acts by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis.
  • It binds to the terminal dipeptide ‘D-ala-D-ala’ sequence of peptidoglycan units—prevents its release from the bactoprenol lipid carrier so that assembly of the units at the cell membrane and their cross linking to form the cell wall cannot take place.
Other options: -
  • Tetracyclines and Clindamycin are protein synthesis inhibitors hence are bacteriostatic
  • Cephalosporins also act as bactericidal, but Vancomycin is a better answer

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 741.

questions.text: A patient with cancer is started on a chemotherapy drug that inhibits DNA transcription by binding to DNA and preventing RNA synthesis. Which of the following drugs acts primarily by inhibiting DNA transcription?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Actinomycin D
 
  • Actinomycin D is an antibacterial agent and a type of antibiotic that inhibits the transcription of DNA into RNA.
  • It does this by binding to the double-stranded DNA helix and blocking the enzyme RNA polymerase from transcribing the genes for protein synthesis.
  • This prevents the cell from being able to translate the DNA into proteins, which halts the growth and replication of the cell. In this way, Actinomycin D is used to stop DNA replication and to inhibit the expression of certain genes.
Other options: 

  • 6-Mercaptopurine inhibits purine synthesis, affecting DNA replication.

  • Mitomycin C is an alkylating agent causing DNA cross-linking, interfering with DNA replication and transcription.

  • Asparaginase depletes asparagine, inhibiting protein synthesis but does not directly inhibit DNA transcription.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 926

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of severe, crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm. ECG reveals ST-elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. He is diagnosed with an acute inferior wall myocardial infarction. As part of the reperfusion strategy, he is administered tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). What is the mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in the treatment of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
• Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) - Alteplase is a fibrinolytic drug which initiates the fibrinolytic pathway, causing activation of plasminogen (particularly, fibrin-found plasminogen) to plasmin which is responsible for the digestion of fibrin, resulting in the breakdown of clot.
  • The t-PA selectively activates fibrin-bound plasminogen within the thrombus, and any plasmin that leaks is inactivated by circulating antiplasmins.
  • Fibrin bound plasmin is not inactivated by antiplasmins because of common binding site for both fibrin and antiplasmin.
  • The t-PA itself is inactivated by plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 and -2 (PAI-1, PAI-2).



Fig: The plasminogen-plasmin system

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 673.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GlST)
 

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs), such as imatinib, are used to treat GISTs, especially when they harbor mutations in c-KIT (CD117) or PDGFRA, both of which are tyrosine kinase receptors.

  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is treated with cytotoxic chemotherapy; some subtypes with FLT3 mutations may use FLT3 inhibitors, but not general TKIs like imatinib.

  • Neurofibromatosis is not treated with TKIs.

  • Small cell carcinoma of the lung is usually treated with chemotherapy (etoposide + platinum-based agents) and is not driven by tyrosine kinase mutations.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 929.

choices.text: No fade on train of four stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fade on tetanic stimulation
 

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that mimics acetylcholine and causes continuous depolarization of the motor endplate, leading to flaccid paralysis. It typically causes a phase I block (unless prolonged use leads to a phase II block).

Key features of Phase I (depolarizing) block:

  • No fade on train-of-four (TOF) or tetanic stimulation

  • No post-tetanic facilitation

  • TOF ratio is typically ≤ 0.4, but all twitches are equally suppressed

  • Fade and post-tetanic facilitation occur only in phase II block, which mimics non-depolarizing block

Hence, statement 2 ("Fade on tetanic stimulation") is incorrect for phase I block, making it the right answer.


On tetanic stimulation, Sch undergoes post-tetanic potentiation instead of fade.
Succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a TOF>0.4

* [Extra Edge]: Clinical assessment of neuromuscular block


FIG: TOF protocol
  • During partial competitive block (as occurs during onset and recovery or reversal) the degree of block corresponds to the decrease in TOF-ratio, because competitive blockers exhibit ‘fade’ phenomenon.
  • As the muscles recover, the TOF-ratio improves and becomes 1.0 at complete recovery.
  • Spontaneous breathing may be resumed when TOF-ratio recovers to > 0.7.
  • On the other hand, classical or phase-I depolarizing block does not exhibit fade; the TOF-ratio remains 1.0, though all the 4 twitches are depressed equally depending on the degree of block.
  • Fade is again seen when phase II or desensitization block occurs with prolonged use of a depolarizing agent and TOF-ratio is depressed as in the case of competitive block. However, SCh generally requires no monitoring.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.
Online Reference:
