Xue L, Wu LG. Post-tetanic potentiation is caused by two signalling mechanisms affecting quantal size and quantal content. J Physiol. 2010 Dec 15;588(Pt 24):4987-94. doi: 10.1113/jphysiol.2010.196964. Epub 2010 Nov 1. PMID: 21041528; PMCID: PMC3036192.

choices.text: Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and prevents its action
Combination produces serious side effects like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease is prescribed sucralfate and ranitidine together. However, his physician advises against taking both medications at the same time. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

Sucralfate requires an acidic environment (pH < 4) to undergo polymerization and bind to ulcer bases, forming a protective barrier. Ranitidine, an H2 receptor blocker, raises gastric pH, thereby reducing the effectiveness of sucralfate.

  • Option 1 is incorrect: There is no direct chemical combination that inactivates either drug.

  • Option 2 is incorrect: This combination does not lead to agranulocytosis.

  • Option 4 is partially true—sucralfate can reduce the absorption of some drugs, but that’s not the main reason the two are not given simultaneously in peptic ulcer therapy.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female college student presents with acute onset retrosternal chest pain and painful swallowing (odynophagia) for 2 days. She recently began taking antibiotics for acne. On endoscopy, there is evidence of mucosal ulceration in the mid-esophagus. What is most frequently linked to pill induced esophagitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Doxycycline
 
  • Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill.
  • Among the options provided, doxycycline is most frequently associated with causing pill-induced esophagitis.
  • The mechanism behind doxycycline-induced esophagitis is thought to be related to its direct irritant effect on the esophageal lining and the potential for local tissue damage.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs causing esophagitis 
  • Doxycycline
  • Quinidine
  • Phenytoin
  • NSAIDs
  • Bisphosphonates
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and interstitial lung disease (ILD) presents for rhythm management. The cardiologist considers initiating antiarrhythmic therapy to maintain sinus rhythm. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient due to risk of pulmonary toxicity? Select the antiarrhythmic drug which needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amiodarone
 
  • Amiodarone is a drug used to treat arrhythmias and is associated with a number of dose dependent pulmonary side effects, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis.
  • The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal.
  • Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/d or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia, ILD appear to be risk factors.
  • Thus, Amiodarone needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases.
  • Serial chest X-rays or pulmonary function studies may detect early amiodarone toxicity but monitoring plasma concentrations has not been useful.
  • With low doses, such as 200 mg/d or less as used in AF, pulmonary toxicity is less common.
Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known contraindication to be used in a patient of ILD
 

Drugs that can cause lung fibrosis (drug-induced interstitial lung disease) include:

Category Examples
Chemotherapeutics Bleomycin, Busulfan, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide
Antiarrhythmics Amiodarone
Antibiotics Nitrofurantoin, Sulfasalazine
Biologics TNF-alpha inhibitors (e.g., Etanercept, Infliximab)
Immunosuppressants Sirolimus, Everolimus

Amiodarone induced pulmonary toxicity 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is started on medication for atrial fibrillation. On follow-up ECG, his QT interval is noted to be prolonged. Which of the following medications is most commonly associated with QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Quinidine
 
  • Quinidine blocks Na+ current and multiple cardiac K+ currents. It is an open-state blocker of Na+ channels, with a τ recovery in the intermediate range. Thus, after therapeutic dosages, QRS duration increases modestly, usually by 10% to 20%.
  • At therapeutic concentrations, quinidine commonly prolongs the QT interval up to 25%, but the effect is highly variable.
  • Drugs causing QTc prolongation - 
  • Category Drugs
    Antiarrhythmics (Class 1a & 3) Quinidine, Procainamide, Disopyramide, Amiodarone, Sotalol, Dofetilide, Ibutilide
    Antibiotics Erythromycin, Clarithromycin, Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Moxifloxacin
    Antifungals Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole
    Antipsychotics Haloperidol, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Olanzapine, Ziprasidone
    Antidepressants Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Citalopram, Escitalopram
    Antiemetics Ondansetron, Granisetron, Domperidone
    Other Drugs Methadone, Chloroquine, Hydroxychloroquine, Lithium, Tacrolimus
Other options: -
2. Amiodarone- class 3 antiarrythmic drug blocks potassium channel, causes QT prolongation but lesser than quinidine.
3. Magnesium sulfate is used in treatment of Torsa des depointes
4. Lignocaine - class 1b antiarryhmic drug doesn't cause QT prolongation 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind theophylline-induced diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Adenosine A1 receptor antagonism

  • Remember TEA - Theophylline - Enzyme inhibitor (PDE) - Adenosine A1 Receptor inhibitor, and is found in tea and coffee
  • Because of PDE inhibition - smooth muscle relaxation - Bronchodialation occurs - hence can be used in the treatment of status asthmaticus
  • Theophylline is an Adenosine receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of adenosine, a neurotransmitter, to A1 and A2a receptors located throughout the body. 
  • The A1 receptor is expressed in the proximal tubule and stimulates reabsorption of Na+. Consequently, antagonists of A1 receptors cause diuresis/natriuresis.
  • S/E due to Adenosine A1 R antagonism - Insomnia, seizures, tachypnea, tachycardia, Diuresis, Nausea and Vomiting (most common)

Option 1, 4 PDE3 and PDE4 are likely account for the bronchodilator action of theophylline which is involve in PDE inhibition and the concomitant elevation of cellular cAMP and cyclic GMP.
Option 3 there is no B2 agonist action of Theophylline.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation is being treated with digoxin. He recently started new medications including aspirin, potassium chloride (KCl), triamterene, and clarithromycin. Shortly afterward, his serum digoxin concentration increases from 2.5 ng/mL to 3.4 ng/mL. He now presents with ECG changes, including T wave thickening. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for the increased serum digoxin concentration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clarithromycin
 
  • MDR1 (P-Glycoprotein) is expressed on the brush border membrane of renal epithelia, and its function can be monitored using digoxin (>70% excreted in the urine).
  • MDR1 inhibitors (e.g., quinidine, verapamil, valspodar, spironolactone, clarithromycin, and ritonavir) all markedly reduce renal excretion of digoxin.
  • This means that more of the drug Digoxin is present in the body for a longer period of time, which can increase the risk of Digoxin toxicity.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs have no enzyme induction or inhibition action significant to Digoxin Metabolism.

* Symptoms of Digoxin toxicity can include,
- Anorexia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain are usually reported first, are due to gastric irritation, mesenteric vasoconstriction and CTZ stimulation.
- Almost every type of arrhythmia can be produced by digoxin, pulsus bigeminies is common; others are nodal and ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and terminally ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs that can cause digoxin toxicity (P glycoprotein/MDR 1 inhibitors) are remembered  as CAVE Q drugs. These include:   

Drugs
C - Clarithromycin, Cyclosporine
A - Amiodarone
V - Verapamil
E - Erythromycin
Q - Quinine/Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text: Which is the most important antibiotic with the phenomenon of "MIC creep"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vancomycin

"MIC creep" refers to a gradual increase in the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic over time while still being within the susceptible range. This may lead to reduced clinical efficacy even though lab susceptibility tests show the organism as "sensitive."

  • Vancomycin is most commonly associated with MIC creep, especially in MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) infections.

  • This gradual increase in MIC can compromise treatment effectiveness and is linked with poor clinical outcomes such as treatment failure and increased mortality.

    Other options:

  • Cotrimoxazole: Resistance can occur, but MIC creep is not a significant concern.

  • Cefazoline: Commonly used for MSSA and surgical prophylaxis; no strong association with MIC creep.

  • Dapsone: Used for leprosy and Pneumocystis prophylaxis; not associated with MIC creep.



Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with sudden onset of eye pain, redness, swelling, and subconjunctival hemorrhage in both eyes. He recently returned from a tropical region where multiple people in his group had similar symptoms. The condition resolved spontaneously in a few days. Which of the following enterovirus serotypes is the most likely cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
• Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC) is a highly contagious viral conjunctivitis characterized by:

    • Sudden onset

    • Pain, photophobia

    • Subconjunctival hemorrhages

    • Often bilateral

    • Self-limiting (resolves in 5–7 days)

  • The most common causative agents are:

    • Enterovirus 70

    • Coxsackievirus A24 variant


      Other options:

    • Enterovirus 68: Causes respiratory illness.

    • Enterovirus 69: Not clinically significant.

    • Enterovirus 71: Associated with hand-foot-and-mouth disease and neurologic complications.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 499.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as a component in the preparation of vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Antiserum
 

  • Live organism

    • Used in live-attenuated vaccines.

    • Example: MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella), BCG, Oral Polio Vaccine.

    • These are weakened forms of the pathogen that stimulate immunity without causing disease.

  • Exotoxin (Toxoid)

    • Used in toxoid vaccines, which are made from inactivated toxins.

    • Example: Diphtheria and Tetanus vaccines.

    • They trigger an immune response against the toxin, not the bacteria.

  • Capsular polysaccharide

    • Used in vaccines targeting encapsulated bacteria.

    • Example: Pneumococcal, Meningococcal, and H. influenzae type b vaccines.

    • Sometimes conjugated with proteins for better immunogenicity, especially in children.

  • Antiserum

    • Not used to prepare vaccines.

    • Antiserum is used for passive immunization, not for inducing active immunity.

    • Example: Rabies immunoglobulin, Tetanus antitoxin.

    • It provides immediate, short-term protection, not long-lasting immunity like vaccines do.
       


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: A 22-year-old sexually active woman presents to the clinic complaining of intense vaginal itching and a thick, white, curdy vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. She denies any foul odor or fever. On examination, the vaginal mucosa is erythematous and inflamed. A wet mount microscopy of the discharge reveals budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. To identify the exact species causing the infection, which of the following diagnostic methods is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is diagnostic of candidiasis.
 
  • For rapid identification of Candida species, CHROMagar is used.
  • It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.
  • Candida albicans colonies appear green. 


Other options: 

  • Sabouraud's dextrose agar can grow Candida but does not differentiate species by color.

  • Enzyme immunoassays and metabolite detection tests are less routinely used and less practical for speciation compared to chromogenic agar.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 680, 700, 702-704.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596, 616.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer from a rural area presents with intermittent fever, night sweats, and joint pain for 3 weeks. Brucellosis is suspected. A serum sample is sent for agglutination testing, but the initial test returns negative. However, when the lab dilutes the patient’s serum and repeats the test, it turns positive. What explains this initial false-negative agglutination result?
questions.solution:
Antibody overproduction occurs in the prozone. Due to their modest size, the immunological complexes generated in this zone are challenging to find. IgG, IgA, and IgM antibodies are discovered using the Standard Agglutination Test. 48 hours are spent incubating the sample at 37 degrees Celsius.
A titre of 1:160 or higher is regarded as important. Prozone phenomenon and the presence of insufficient or blocking antibodies are both associated with false negative SAT.


Other options:

  • Postzone phenomenon happens with excess antigen, which is not the case here.

  • Early infection may cause low antibody levels, but that would not explain positivity on dilution.

  • Complement-mediated interference is not a typical cause of false-negative agglutination tests.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Category A bioterrorism agents are biological agents that have the potential to cause mass casualties and panic.
Category A bioterrorism agents include

  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis)
  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (variola major)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (filoviruses [e.g., Ebola, Marburg] and arenaviruses [e.g., Lassa, Machupo])
Category B- Minority priority agents, Moderately well disseminated, Moderate morbidity and low mortality. Eg- Coxiella burnetti, Burkholderia mallei, Burkholderia psedomallei, Ricin toxin, Cryptosporidum parvum, Salmonella typhi, Chlamydia psittaci.

Category C- Low priority agents, could be engineered for mass dissemination, Readily available, Easy to produce, Potentially high morbidity and mortality. Eg- Emergent viruses: Nipah and Hantavirus, corona, H1N1, Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 662.

questions.text: In which of the following infections are Owl’s Eye inclusion bodies characteristically seen on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CMV 
 

Owl’s Eye inclusion bodies are large, eosinophilic nuclear inclusions seen in cells infected with Cytomegalovirus (CMV). These inclusions have a characteristic appearance resembling the eyes of an owl and are considered a hallmark of CMV infection.

  • Adenovirus causes basophilic nuclear inclusions but not Owl’s Eye inclusions.

  • Smallpox and Vaccinia virus (both poxviruses) produce cytoplasmic inclusions (Guarnieri bodies), not Owl’s Eye nuclear inclusions.






Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with left-sided facial pain, swelling, and redness around his eye. He also reports bloody nasal discharge and difficulty opening his mouth. On examination, there is periorbital edema and tenderness. Nasal endoscopy reveals necrotic tissue in the nasal cavity. A sample from periorbital pus is sent for culture, which reveals branching septate hyphae on microscopy. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
• This patient’s presentation suggests invasive fungal sinusitis, which is a medical emergency. It commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially those with poorly controlled diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis.

  • The presence of facial pain, periorbital swelling, necrotic nasal tissue, and bloody nasal discharge are typical signs of invasive fungal infection of the sinuses extending into the orbit (orbital cellulitis or orbital apex syndrome).

  • The fungal culture showed branching septate hyphae, which is characteristic of Aspergillus species. Aspergillus causes invasive sinus and pulmonary infections, especially in immunocompromised hosts, and appears as thin, regularly branching septate hyphae under microscopy.

  • Mucor and Rhizopus species, which cause mucormycosis, also affect diabetics but their hyphae are broad, irregularly branched, and aseptate (non-septate). These fungi are highly angioinvasive and cause rapid tissue necrosis but differ microscopically.

  • Candida species form yeast and pseudohyphae, not true septate hyphae, and are less commonly associated with necrotizing sinus infections.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with headache, high-grade fever and features suggestive of encephalitis. Bilateral temporal hemorrhages are seen on MRI. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
A 25-year old female presents with infectious encephalitis with findings of bilateral temporal hemorrhages.

  • The clue to the etiology arises from the affinity of the pathogen for the temporal lobes, as they are affected bilaterally and there is extensive destruction progressing to hemorrhage.
This correlates most closely with the presentation of HSV-encephalitis, usually caused by HSV-1. 

Other options: 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis generally causes chronic meningitis with basal exudates, not hemorrhagic temporal lobe lesions.

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae causes bacterial meningitis, which presents with meningeal signs and diffuse brain involvement but not focal bilateral temporal hemorrhages.

  • Cryptococcus neoformans causes subacute meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients, without characteristic hemorrhagic temporal lobe involvement.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 451.

choices.text: Transmitted when adult mites feed on hosts

questions.text: Which of the following statements about scrub typhus is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
• Orientia tsutsugamushi is the causative organism of scrub typhus.

  • The vector and reservoir are larval stage mites (chiggers), not adult mites. Transmission occurs during the larval mite’s feeding.

  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice and is highly effective.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps after a recent course of antibiotics. Clostridium difficile infection is suspected. Which of the following tests is best for diagnosing Clostridium difficile–associated diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of clostridium difficile diarrhea is based on detection of toxin or the organism in stool smaples.
 
  • The toxin can be detected using nucleic acid amplification testing methods such as polymerase chain reaction or by culture. 
 
  • On endoscopy, it can be diagnosed by visualization of pseudo membrane. 
 
  • The drug of choice for pseudomembranous enterocolitis is Oral fidaxomicin. 
Other options: 

  • Cell culture cytotoxin test detects the presence of toxins but is more time-consuming and less commonly used now.

  • Stool culture for C. difficile is slow, and culture alone does not distinguish between toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains.

  • Blood culture is not useful as C. difficile infection is localized to the gut.





Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1066-1069.

questions.text: A 40-year-old truck driver with known HIV-1 infection presents with sudden onset of breathlessness, fever, and lymphadenopathy. Pleural effusion is noted on examination. Culture of pleural fluid shows a dimorphic fungus with mold form at 25°C and yeast form at 37°C, producing red pigmentation in colonies. What is the most likely causative organism and the drug of choice for treatment?
questions.solution:
The most likely organism based on clinical history and histopathological findings is Penicillium marneffei (3). 
 
  • It is dimorphic fungus which causes talaromycosis commonly seen in people with advanced AIDS. On blood culture, the organism shows mold with powdery surface and red pigment which diffuses in the agar. 
 
  • On HPE, it shows yeast like organisms with central septation. 
 
  • Treatment- Itraconazole is used for treatment for mild to moderate cases whereas for severe cases, amphotericin B is used. 
Other options:

  • 1. Pneumocystis jirovecii, Cotrimoxazole: Causes pneumonia but is not dimorphic and does not produce pigment.

  • 2. Candida albicans, Amphotericin-B: Candida is yeast only and does not have a dimorphic form or red pigment.

  • 4. Aspergillus, Voriconazole: Aspergillus is a mold, not dimorphic, and does not produce red pigment.




Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1666, 1688, 1692.

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 612-614.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is born to a mother known to be HIV-positive. The pediatrician wants to confirm or rule out HIV infection in the neonate. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to detect HIV infection in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of HIV in a newborn baby born to an HIV-infected mother is done using a polymerase chain reaction. Antibody, ELISA are not used due to maternal transmission causing false-positivity.

Recommended testing:
  • HIV DNA or RNA PCR should be performed at birth, 1–2 months, and 4–6 months in high-risk infants.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made when two separate PCR tests are positive.

Other options:
 
  • Detection of HIV-antibodies in neonate: Not reliable because maternal HIV antibodies can cross the placenta and persist in the infant’s circulation for up to 18 months, even if the baby is not infected.
  • PCR: Detects HIV DNA or RNA and is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing HIV infection in neonates. It can identify the virus directly, even in the presence of maternal antibodies.
  • ELISA: Not suitable for neonates for the same reason as antibody detection — it primarily detects antibodies, which may be maternal in origin.
  • p24 antigen: Has lower sensitivity in neonates and is not as reliable as PCR for early diagnosis.


Reference: Essenrial Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 228, 229.

questions.text: A 5-year-old unvaccinated boy is brought to the clinic with a 4-day history of high-grade fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and runny nose. On examination, you note clustered white lesions on the buccal mucosa opposite the upper first and second molars. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of these lesions?
questions.solution:
• Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles (rubeola).

  • They are tiny, white or bluish-white lesions on the buccal mucosa, typically opposite the upper molars.

  • These lesions appear before the classic maculopapular rash and are an early diagnostic clue.

    Other options: 

  • Leukoplakia: White patches in the oral mucosa, often precancerous, and not associated with measles.

  • Kaposi spots: No such term in this context; possibly a distractor.

  • None: Incorrect, as these lesions have a specific name in measles.



 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 559.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, and seizures. MRI shows bilateral temporal lobe hyperintensities suggestive of herpes encephalitis. What is the most appropriate next investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In this patient with encephalitis, a provisional diagnosis of herpes encephalitis is based on neuroimaging by MRI.
  • The gold standard for establishing the diagnosis is the detection of herpes simplex virus DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
  • The T2 weighted MRI of the brain will show Hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in the most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.
  • Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis. 

Other options: 

  • Serum IgM is less useful because it indicates systemic infection and not necessarily CNS involvement.

  • CSF culture is usually negative as HSV does not grow well in routine culture.

  • Tzanck smear is used for skin lesions, not CSF.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1095.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man receives a rabies vaccine after a dog bite. Two weeks later, he develops fever, headache, and confusion. MRI brain shows signs of encephalitis. His symptoms are thought to be due to an autoimmune reaction triggered by the vaccine. This autoimmune reaction is most likely caused by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Molecular mimicry 
 

  1. Molecular mimicry — Correct answer
    This occurs when the immune system mistakes self-antigens for foreign antigens because of structural similarity. In rabies vaccine encephalitis, antibodies generated against the viral proteins cross-react with neural tissue, triggering autoimmune encephalitis.

  2. Sequestrated antigen exposure
    This refers to immune responses triggered by previously hidden (sequestered) self-antigens exposed during tissue injury. It is less relevant here since the encephalitis is caused by a cross-reaction, not by exposure of hidden antigens.

  3. Alteration of C antigen
    This is a rare mechanism where an antigen is chemically altered, creating new antigenic determinants. It’s not implicated in rabies vaccine-induced encephalitis.

  4. Epitope spreading
    This mechanism involves diversification of the immune response from the initial antigenic epitope to other epitopes, potentially worsening autoimmunity over time. While it can contribute to autoimmune disease progression, the primary mechanism here is molecular mimicry.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 539.

choices.text: Unlawful under the article 19 of the constitution

questions.text: Force-feeding of prisoners who are on hunger strike is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lawful under article 21 of the constitution.

Force-feeding of prisoners who are on a hunger strike could potentially be considered lawful under Article 21 if it is done in exceptional circumstances to protect the life of the prisoner. The State's duty to preserve life may outweigh the individual's right to refuse food when it poses an imminent threat to their life

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: Corpus Delicti refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Body of offence

Corpus delicti is a Latin term meaning "body of the crime/offence." It is the essential facts that prove that a crime has been committed. For example, a person cannot be convicted of Shoplifting unless the prosecutor can demonstrate the property was stolen.  Here, the stealing of the item becomes “corpus delicti.”

Other options:

Dead body – Incorrect. Corpus delicti does not mean just a dead body. It refers to proof that a crime has actually occurred, not just the presence of a corpse.
 

Inquest – Incorrect. An inquest is a judicial inquiry, usually into the cause of a death, but it is not the same as corpus delicti.

Enquiry by police – Incorrect. Police inquiry or investigation is the process of gathering evidence, but corpus delicti specifically relates to proof that a crime occurred.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 57.

questions.text: What is Virchow's dissection technique?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Individual organ Removal and dissection.
 

  • Virchow's technique involves removing and dissecting each organ individually to examine them in detail. It is the most commonly used technique in modern autopsies because it allows thorough examination of each organ separately.

  • Block dissection (Option 1) refers to removing multiple organs together as a single block before separating them.

  • En masse dissection (Option 2) means removing the thoracic and abdominal organs together in one piece.

  • Organ dissection in situ (Option 4) means dissecting the organs without removing them from the body.




Memorizing Technique-
RokItansky's- Infection- In situ
LetullE's- En masse
Ghon- Ghon's focus in TB- Focussed removal- En block method
Virchow's- organ by organ

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 109.

questions.text: Did you see that Mr. "A" killed Mr. "B"?" was the question the attorney posed to the witness while they were documenting the evidence in a courtroom. Witness responded, "Yes." This kind of inquiry is accepted in?
questions.solution:
• Cross examination allows leading questions (questions that suggest the answer) to challenge the credibility of the witness or clarify testimony. Asking "Did you see that Mr. 'A' killed Mr. 'B'?" is a leading question, which is allowed during cross examination.

  • Examination in Chief (also called direct examination) involves open-ended questions to get the witness’s narrative without leading them.

  • Re-examination follows cross examination and aims to clarify issues raised, but leading questions are generally not allowed.

  • The terms Examination in Chief and Direct examination are often used interchangeably.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 14.

questions.text: A 10 years old boy presented to the Emergency department with vomiting. Parents said that he had consumed 15 tablets of ferrous sulphate. Which drug should be used in such a patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is  suggestive of iron toxicity due to consumption of FeSO4 talets.
 
  • It is managed by administration of an iron chelator which among the given options is Option 3-Desferrioxamine.
 

Iron toxicity occurs when there is excessive iron in the body, leading to oxidative damage and cellular injury. It can be acute (from overdose) or chronic (from conditions like hemochromatosis).

Causes:

  • Acute: Accidental ingestion (common in children) or intentional overdose.
  • Chronic: Repeated blood transfusions, hereditary hemochromatosis, or excessive dietary supplementation.
Clinical phases of Acute toxicity:
 
  1. Gastrointestinal Stage (0–6 hours): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and hematemesis. Severe cases may show hypovolemic shock.
  2. Latent Phase (6–24 hours): Temporary resolution of symptoms, potentially masking ongoing systemic damage.
  3. Shock/Metabolic Stage (6–72 hours): Multiorgan failure, acidosis, hypotension, liver injury, coagulopathy, and hypoglycemia.
  4. Hepatic Stage (2–5 days): Fulminant liver failure, coagulopathy, and encephalopathy.
  5. Recovery Stage (2–4 weeks): Resolution with potential long-term complications like strictures in the gastrointestinal tract.
Mechanism: 

Excess iron generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing oxidative stress and damage to cellular structures, particularly in the liver, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnosis

  • Elevated serum iron levels (>300–500 µg/dL).
  • Increased anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Radiographic imaging may show radiopaque iron tablets in the stomach.
  • Evidence of liver dysfunction (elevated ALT/AST).
Management:
  1. Decontamination:
    • Gastric lavage (if ingestion is recent).
    • Whole bowel irrigation for significant ingestion.
  2. Supportive Care:
    • IV fluids, correction of metabolic acidosis, and management of shock.
  3. Chelation Therapy:
    • Deferoxamine: Binds free iron and facilitates its excretion in urine.
  4. Severe Cases:
    • Consider dialysis for iron chelate removal if deferoxamine fails.
    • Monitor for liver and cardiac complications.
Prognosis
  • Prompt treatment improves outcomes.
  • Delayed care or severe cases may lead to death or permanent organ damage.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 548.

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2343, 2588, 2847, 3236.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found dead at his home. On autopsy, a greenish discoloration is noted over the right lower abdomen, around the iliac fossa region. This greenish color is most likely due to the accumulation of which of the following substances during putrefaction?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sulphmethemoglobin

Greenish discoloration results from the conversion of haemoglobin of blood into sulphmethaemoglobin by the hydrogen sulphide formed in the large intestine and escaping into the surrounding tissues

The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying in air is usually a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

The order of putrefaction from 1st organ to last is 
  • Larynx and Trachea
  • Stomach and intestine
  • Lungs and liver
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney
  • Prostate and Uterus
  • Muscles, tendons
  • Skin
  • Bones 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33RD Edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: During harvest season, a farmer was sleeping when he woke up due to a bite. He became drowsy and was brought to the hospital. The wound became red with pain and patient had profuse bleeding. Which of the following was the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The farmer has been bitten by an unidentified animal in the harvest season while sleeping. There is drowsiness with local signs of redness, pain, and continuous bleeding. This is likely to be hemotoxic snake bite envenomation like vipers (ophiotoxaemia).

Viperine bites are characterized by:
  • Severe pain within 8 minutes
  • Onset of swelling within 15 minutes
  • Blood-staining discharge from the wound, with persistent bleeding
  • Blisters in 12 hours in and around the bite site, progressing to involve the entire limb.

Other options:

  • Cobra bites cause neurotoxic symptoms (paralysis) with minimal local bleeding.

  • Scorpion stings cause pain and neurotoxic symptoms but not bleeding.

  • Wasp stings cause localized pain and allergic reactions but not severe bleeding or systemic drowsiness.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 563.

choices.text: Killing mother in an attempt to kill the fetus
Killing of fetus with consent of mother
Killing of fetus without consent of mother
Killing fetus in an attempt to kill the mother amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 of IPC deals with:-
questions.solution:
The legal aspects of criminal abortion are dealt with under sections 312 to 316 of the IPC.

Section 314 of the IPC - death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage:
  • Intent: causing miscarriage of a pregnant woman
  • Act: Causes death of woman (killing of mother); irrespective of whether that offender knew that the act is likely to cause death
  • Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 10 years and fine.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33th Edition, Page. No- 401.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male working in a paint factory for the past 20 years presents with fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia, and joint pains. Blood tests reveal anemia. Which enzyme is most likely inhibited in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning and the enzyme affected in this case is option 4- aminolevulinic acid dehydratase or ALA dehydratase. 

The other key enzyme of heme metabolism pathway inhibited by lead is ferrochelatase. 
 

The patient's symptoms (fatigue, constipation, headache, insomnia, joint pains) along with anemia and long-term exposure in a paint factory suggest lead poisoning. Lead poisoning inhibits key enzymes involved in the heme synthesis pathway, particularly:

  1. ALA dehydratase (delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase):
    • Lead directly inhibits this enzyme, leading to the accumulation of ALA (delta-aminolevulinic acid) in the blood and urine.
    • This contributes to anemia and neurological symptoms.
  2. Ferrochelatase (not listed as an option):
    • Lead also inhibits ferrochelatase, causing the accumulation of protoporphyrin in red blood cells.
Other options: 
 
  1. Uroporphyrinogen I synthase: Associated with acute intermittent porphyria, not lead poisoning.
  2. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: Deficiency causes congenital erythropoietic porphyria, unrelated to lead exposure.
  3. ALA synthase: This enzyme is regulated by heme levels but is not directly inhibited by lead.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 544, 545.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with hair loss on the scalp and eyebrows, along with behavioral changes. On examination, the doctor inspects the nails for diagnosis. The most likely cause of poisoning is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hair loss, loss of eyebrows with behavioral and nail changes goes in favour of thallium poisoning. 

Hair loss characteristically involves lateral thirds of the eyebrows. Mees lines are seen in nails.



Other options: 

  • Arsenic poisoning also causes Mees’ lines on nails but usually presents with skin changes and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than eyebrow loss.

  • Lead poisoning mainly affects the nervous system and causes anemia but is not associated with hair loss or eyebrow loss.

  • Mercury poisoning causes neurological symptoms and stomatitis but not hair loss or specific nail findings like in thallium poisoning.



Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 548.

choices.text: Child delivered after death of biological mother
Child delivered after death of biological father

questions.text: Posthumous child is best defined as a child who is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Child delivered after death of biological father

A child born after the death of the biological father is known as posthumous child. There can be some legal implications in such a case like Inheritance, Naming, Social security, Parental rights etc.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 396.

questions.text: A poor farmer from a drought-affected region presents with progressive spastic paresis, upper motor neuron signs, and gait instability. He reports a history of consuming locally harvested grains after successive crop failures. Which toxin is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Beta oxalyl amino alanine

The scenario involves a poor farmer with successive crop failures, with signs of gait dysfunction and signs of UMN disease due to consumption of a toxin, this is likely to be a case of neurolathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/ Lathyrus sativus which contains Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOA) (toxic compound causing lathyrism).
The toxin present in lathyrus seeds has been identified as Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). It has been isolated in crystalline form and is water soluble; this property has been made use of in removing the toxin from the pulse by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soak water.
Studies indicate that there is a blood-brain barrier to this toxin. In order to overcome this barrier, the pulse must be eaten in large amounts over a period of time for 2 months or more. Besides BOAA several other toxins have also been reported.

Other options:

  • Sanguinarine is a plant alkaloid associated with oral leukoplakia but not spastic paralysis.

  • Aflatoxin is a hepatotoxic and carcinogenic mycotoxin from Aspergillus species, primarily causing liver damage and cancer.

  • Ergot alkaloids cause ergotism with vasospasm and ischemia, manifesting as gangrene or convulsions, not isolated UMN spastic paresis.


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 701.

questions.text: Brown Tumors are seen in:
questions.solution:
1. Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism leads to decreased metabolism and can cause features like myxedema and delayed bone growth in children but does not cause Brown tumors. Bone changes in hypothyroidism are not related to osteoclastic activity seen in Brown tumors.

  1. Hyperthyroidism

  • Hyperthyroidism causes increased bone turnover and osteoporosis but is not associated with Brown tumors. It may cause generalized bone loss but not localized lytic lesions typical of Brown tumors.

  1. Hypoparathyroidism

  • Hypoparathyroidism causes low parathyroid hormone levels leading to hypocalcemia and increased bone density (osteosclerosis), not Brown tumors. It suppresses osteoclastic activity.

  1. Hyperparathyroidism

  • Brown tumors are a classic skeletal manifestation of hyperparathyroidism, caused by excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH increases osteoclastic activity, causing bone resorption, cyst-like lesions filled with fibrous tissue and giant cells, known as Brown tumors due to hemosiderin deposition.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 313

questions.text: A 28-year-old athlete complains of lateral knee pain that worsens with running. On physical examination, the Ober's test is performed and found to be positive. Which of the following conditions is being assessed by Ober's test?
questions.solution:
Ober's test is used in evaluation of iliotibial band contracture.


Other options:

  • SI joint involvement in ankylosing spondylitis:
    FABER test (Patrick’s test) — pain in SI joint when hip is flexed, abducted, externally rotated, and pressure applied.

  • Patellar tendinitis:
    Tenderness at patellar tendon with pain on resisted knee extension.

  • Posterior shoulder dislocation:
    Jerk test — sudden clunk with horizontal adduction and internal rotation of flexed shoulder.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 368

questions.text: A 42-year-old man undergoes laparoscopic bilateral inguinal hernia repair. Postoperatively, he complains of burning pain and numbness in the anterolateral aspect of his thigh. The pain worsens with standing or wearing tight clothing. On examination, there is no motor weakness. Which of the following nerves was most likely injured during surgery?
questions.solution:
The patient has presented with lower limb pain post laparoscopic bilateral inguinal surgery.
This is most likely due to entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve resulting in meralgia paresthetica.
Pain after inguinal hernia repair is classified into acute or chronic manifestations of three mechanisms:
  • Nociceptive (somatic): most common
  • Neuropathic:
    • Direct nerve damage
    • Entrapment (as in this patient)
  • Visceral pain: may occur during ejaculation as a result of sympathetic plexus injury
The nerves injured in laparoscopic repair are:
  1. Genitofemoral nerve
  2. Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Other options:

  • Ilioinguinal nerve – Innervates the skin of the upper medial thigh, root of penis/scrotum or mons pubis/labia. Injury causes pain in groin, not lateral thigh.

  • Iliohypogastric nerve – Supplies the skin over the iliac crest and suprapubic area. Injury causes burning or numbness in lower abdomen or hip area, not the thigh.

  • Femoral nerve – Supplies anterior thigh muscles and skin. Injury leads to quadriceps weakness and sensory loss over anterior thigh and medial leg — not isolated anterolateral thigh pain.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1119.

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Adductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and Flexor pollicis brevis
Adductor pollicis longus and Flexor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female who recently gave birth presents with pain on the radial side of her right wrist, especially while lifting her baby or turning door knobs. On physical exam, there is tenderness over the radial styloid and a positive Finkelstein test. Which of the following tendons are most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis, also known as washerwoman's sprain/strain, is a painful stenosing tenosynovitis involving the first extensor (dorsal) tendon compartment of the wrist (typically at the radial styloid).
  • This compartment contains the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons.
  • De Quervain tenosynovitis, the tendons become inflamed and irritated as they pass through this narrow tunnel, causing pain and discomfort in the thumb and wrist. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 303

questions.text: Which of the numbered bones in the X-ray given below gets fractured most frequently when an elderly person falls on their outstretched hands?
questions.solution:
1-Radius, is most commonly fractured in elderly following fall on an outstretched hand.
2- Ulna
3- 2nd metacarpal
4- 3rd metacarpal

The distal radius is  closest to the wrist joint, and it is particularly vulnerable to fractures in this type of fall because it is responsible for transmitting much of the force from the hand to the forearm resulting in Colle's fracture. 

FOOSH injury (Fall On Outstretched Hand) is a common mechanism of injury that can involve various bones in the upper limb depending on the age, force, and position of the hand during the fall. Here is a concise table summarizing the bones commonly involved based on the site of injury:
 
Site of Injury Common Bones Involved Common Injury Pattern
Wrist Scaphoid, Distal radius Scaphoid fracture, Colles' fracture
Forearm Radius, Ulna Galeazzi fracture (radius fx + distal radioulnar joint), Monteggia fracture (ulna fx + radial head dislocation)
Elbow Radial head, Supracondylar humerus (children) Radial head fracture (adults), Supracondylar fracture (kids)
Shoulder/Clavicle Clavicle, Proximal humerus, Glenoid Clavicle fracture, Proximal humerus fracture, Shoulder dislocation
Hand Carpal bones (esp. scaphoid, lunate), metacarpals Scaphoid fracture, Lunate dislocation, Boxer's fracture (5th metacarpal)

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 36

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy undergoes surgery for congenital aural atresia. Postoperative findings include widening of the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal to improve ventilation and drainage. Which of the following procedures was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
• Meatoplasty: A surgical procedure involving the widening of the external auditory canal, particularly the cartilaginous portion, to enhance ventilation and access. Commonly performed in chronic otitis externa, after canaloplasty, or in congenital aural atresia surgery.

  • Otoplasty: Cosmetic procedure to correct deformities of the external ear (pinna), not the canal.

  • Myringoplasty: Surgical repair of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) only, without ossicular reconstruction.

  • Tympanoplasty: Surgical reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and/or ossicles for hearing improvement, but does not address the canal directly.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 455

choices.text: Most common site of CSF leak is cribiform plate
Beta transferrin estimation is highly specific for diagnosis of leak
Fluorescein Dye can be used intrathecally for diagnosis of site of leak
MRI (Gadolinium enhanced) IT images are best for diagnosis of site of leak

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with clear nasal discharge following a head trauma 1 week ago. The fluid is positive for beta-2 transferrin. You are evaluating imaging options to localize the site of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak. Which of the following statements regarding CSF leaks is false?
questions.solution:
• Option(4() is a false statement.
  • HRCT base of the skull is the best investigation for localizing the site of the leak not MRI. CT Cisternography in which dye is put intrathecally is done to localize the site during an active csf leak.
  • Other statements are True. 
Other options
  • Option 1 -  The cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone is ithe most common site for spontaneous or traumatic CSF leaks due to its thin structure and proximity to the nasal cavity. 
  • Option 2 -  Beta-2 transferrin is a protein found almost exclusively in CSF (and to a lesser extent in vitreous humor and perilymph). Its detection in nasal or ear fluid is a highly specific for CSF Rhinorrhoea. 
  • Option 3 - Intrathecal fluorescein, injected into the spinal subarachnoid space, is a well-established technique to localize the site of a CSF leak, particularly in complex cases. It is visualized under endoscopy or imaging as it leaks out.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 184

choices.text: Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are 940 nm and 660 nm

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is undergoing monitoring during a routine surgery. A pulse oximeter is used to continuously monitor his oxygenation status. Regarding pulse oximetry, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Heart rate can be measured with pulse oximeter.
  • Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive method of measuring the oxygen saturation (SpO2) in arterial blood.
  • It measures the absorption of light by hemoglobin in the blood, which varies depending on whether the hemoglobin is carrying oxygen or not.
  • The pulse oximeter uses two wavelengths of light, typically 660 nm and 940 nm, to measure the oxygen saturation.
  • The ratio of the absorption of these two wavelengths is used to calculate the SpO2.
  • Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are  940 nm and 660 nm as mentioned in option 2.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because pulse oximetry can also measure heart rate by detecting changes in blood volume during each pulse. 


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1301, 1302.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with bowel obstruction is taken to the OR for emergency laparotomy. He is at high risk of aspiration. The anesthesiologist decides to use a traditional rapid sequence induction (RSI) for anesthesia. Which of the following is NOT considered a mandatory component of traditional RSI?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. IV adrenaline
 
  • Traditional Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) is a technique used to rapidly induce anesthesia while minimizing the risk of aspiration of gastric contents like pregnancy, obstruction. 
  • Order: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1382, 1383.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with a chromosomal disorder characterized by intellectual disability, distinct facial features, and hypotonia. Which of the following terms historically has been used synonymously with Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. OLIGOPHRENIA
 
  • The term "oligophrenia" refers to a condition of limited mental ability or intellectual disability.
  • Down syndrome is a type of oligophrenia, as individuals with this condition have varying degrees of intellectual disability.
Other options:

  • Mental disorder is a broad term referring to psychiatric illnesses, not specific to intellectual disability.

  • Madness is an outdated and non-medical term often referring to psychosis or severe mental illness.

  • Mentally unstable is a nonspecific and informal term not used in medical diagnosis.



Reference: Classification of Oligophrenia and their Clinical and Pedagogical Features, Umarova Saboxon Minavvarovna, Erkinova Sarvinoz Mashrabjon qizi doi: https://cejsr.academicjournal.io/index.php/journal/article/download/741/675/1971

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is undergoing behavioral therapy for smoking cessation. The therapist discusses different stages of behavior change to help the patient progress towards quitting. Which of the following is NOT considered a stage or part of the cognitive behavior change process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CONSOLIDATION
 
  • The following question is based on the TRANSTHEORITICAL MODEL OF CHANGE.
  • This theory emphasizes the fact that the behavioural change of an individual occurs through 6 stages:
  1. PRE-CONTEMPLATION - The person denies problems and their consequences
  2. CONTEMPLATION - The person acknowledges problem but is unwilling to change
  3. PREPARATION - Committed to and planning for behaviour change
  4. ACTION - Executes plan and demonstrates a change in behaviour
  5. MAINTENANCE - new behaviours are integrated in lifestyle
  6. RELAPSE -Regression to prior behaviour. It doesn’t occur frequently.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 623.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) two months ago. Since then, he has been experiencing recurrent distressing dreams where he vividly re-experiences the accident scene. He avoids returning to the site of the accident due to intense fear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. PTSD

The given clinical vignette describes the condition - PTSD
A few important points about PTSD:-
  • Timeline – more than 1 month
  • 4 important features: - Hyperarousal, Avoidance of associated stimulus, Reexperiencing the events through flashbacks and dreams (Important buzzword usually given in clinical vignette), Distress and fear.
  • Management- SSRI, CBT, EMDR
Other options:

  • Adjustment disorder involves emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to a stressor but typically does not include re-experiencing symptoms or vivid nightmares.

  • Anxiety disorder is a broader category without specific trauma-related symptoms.

  • OCD involves obsessions and compulsions, not trauma-related re-experiencing or avoidance.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 429, 172-174.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents with symptoms including overfamiliar behavior, racing thoughts, an elevated mood, increased sexual drive, and reports of pseudo-hallucinations. These symptoms have lasted for about one week and are causing significant impairment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Mania involves elevated or irritable mood, increased activity or energy, racing thoughts, disinhibition (including heightened sexual drive), and may include psychotic features such as hallucinations or delusions. Pseudo-hallucinations occur when the patient is aware that the hallucinations are not real, often seen in manic states with psychotic symptoms.

  • Schizomania is an outdated term sometimes used to describe manic episodes with psychotic features but is not commonly used in current diagnostic systems.

  • Hypomania is a milder form of mania, usually without psychotic symptoms and less functional impairment.

  • Cyclothymia involves milder mood swings lasting at least 2 years without full criteria for mania or major depression.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 292, 293, 348, 358.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with known HIV infection has been on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) for the past 6 months. He presents for routine follow-up. Which of the following tests is the best indicator to evaluate the efficacy of his antiretroviral treatment?
questions.solution:
The evaluation of efficacy of HAART in a case of HIV is done with the help of viral load. 
 

In a known case of HIV undergoing Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART), the efficacy of the treatment is primarily evaluated by measuring the viral load. This is the amount of HIV RNA present in the blood.

  • Viral load: The main indicator of treatment efficacy. If HAART is effective, the viral load should decrease significantly over time and ideally become undetectable (usually <20-50 copies/ml). A decrease in viral load indicates that the treatment is working to suppress the virus. Monitoring viral load helps assess how well the antiretroviral therapy is controlling the virus.

Other options:
 

  • ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay): This is primarily used for HIV screening and not for evaluating the efficacy of HAART. It detects HIV antibodies but doesn't provide direct information about viral replication or treatment success.

  • p24 antigen: This test detects a core protein of HIV and can be used in early HIV infection (before antibodies develop), but it's not routinely used to assess the efficacy of HAART in an established HIV infection.

  • Western blot: This is a confirmatory test for HIV infection after an initial positive screening test (e.g., ELISA). It's not used to assess the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1560, 1595, 1596.

questions.text: A patient presented with pitting of nails, subungual hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Irregular pitting of nails, subungal hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes are seen in psoriasis. 



Other options:

  • Lichen planus causes longitudinal ridging, thinning, and nail loss but not classic oil-drop changes.

  • Onychomycosis presents with nail thickening and discoloration but usually lacks pitting and oil-drop signs.

  • Tuberous sclerosis can have nail fibromas but does not cause these specific nail changes.



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 35.1, 35.8, 35.9, 35.10.

questions.text: A known case of borderline tuberculoid leprosy was undergoing treatment. Which of the following nerve is commonly affected in such a case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is in favor of leprosy. The most common cranial nerve involved in leprosy is 7th cranial nerve. 
 
  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes.
  • The posterior tibial nerve is most commonly involved, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • The facial nerve is the most frequently affected cranial nerve.
  • Leprosy has a prolonged incubation period, typically ranging from 2 to 12 years. It often presents as a numb area on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which may appear as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.
  • Lesions typically occur on the face, extensor surfaces of the limbs, trunk, and buttocks. These lesions are associated with impaired nerve function and poor hair growth. Patients may also develop burns or ulcers on the affected anesthetic limb.


Leprosy is classified using two main systems:

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tuberculoid (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
 
  • WHO classification:
    • Paucibacillary
    • Multibacillary



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.13.

questions.text: An obese lady presented to the Skin OPD with the complaints of dark patches over neck as shown in the figure. It is associated with:
questions.solution:
• Acanthosis nigricans is characterized by hyperpigmented, thickened, velvety plaques commonly seen in the neck, axilla, and other folds (AS SHOWN IN THE IMAGE)

  • It is strongly associated with insulin resistance and is commonly seen in obesity and metabolic syndrome.

  • Insulin resistance leads to increased insulin-like growth factor receptor activity, stimulating keratinocyte proliferation and pigmentation.

  • Addison disease causes generalized hyperpigmentation due to increased ACTH but not typical acanthosis nigricans.

  • Cushing syndrome causes skin thinning, striae, and bruising but not acanthosis nigricans.

  • Hypothyroidism may cause dry skin and myxedema but is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 390, 2933, 2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3154-3156.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with swelling on the hard palate as shown. Which of the following is the most common condition causing this?
questions.solution:
The HIV positive patient with multiple, firm-appearing violaceous plaques on the hard palate is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, a multifocal epithelial tumor attributed to HPV-8 infection.
  • KS is considered an AIDS-defining illness.
  • The intraoral site most commonly affected is the palate followed by the gingiva.
Other options:

  • Basal cell carcinoma rarely occurs in the oral cavity.

  • Squamous cell carcinoma can occur in the oral cavity but is less common than Kaposi sarcoma in HIV-positive patients, and usually presents as ulcerative or exophytic lesions rather than violaceous swellings.

  • Malignant melanoma is rare in the oral cavity and usually presents as pigmented lesions, but is uncommon in HIV patients compared to Kaposi sarcoma.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 520, 522.

choices.text: USG monitoring till size of the aneurysm reaches 70 mm

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with mild abdominal pain. Imaging reveals an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is hemodynamically stable with no signs of rupture. What is the most appropriate management step?
questions.solution:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common type of large vessel aneurysm, found in 2% of the population. It usually remains asymptomatic, but may cause mild symptoms like back pain and abdominal discomfort.
However, rupture of an aneurysm produces severe pain in the back and abdomen, in addition to hypotension. The annual risk of rupture is low (1% or less) for aneurysms that are smaller than 55 mm in diameter, but increases significantly (up to 25%) for aneurysms with a diameter of 70 mm or more. Regular ultrasound assessments are indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms smaller than 55 mm in diameter, and repair of the aneurysm should be considered if the diameter is greater than 55 mm.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: An elderly male presents to the surgery outpatient department with pain and swelling in the scrotum, fever, and redness with cellulitis of the scrotal skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with image findings of gangrenous scrotal wall goes in favour of Fournier's gangrene. 
  • It is a polymicrobial infection involving the subcutaneous tissue leading to obliterative arteritis and gangrene. 
  • Management is emergency surgical debridement. 
  • Testis are usually spared in Fournier's gangrene due to dual blood supply. 


FOURNIER Gangrene Mnemonic: “F-O-U-R-N-I-E-R”

  • F — Fistula (perianal fistula, rectal fistula)

  • O — Obesity and Old age

  • U — Urinary tract infection / Urethral trauma

  • R — Diabetes (R for “sugar” / Risk factor)

  • N — Neoplasm (colorectal or urogenital cancers)

  • I — Immunosuppression (HIV, steroids)

  • E — E. coli and other Enterobacteriaceae (main bacterial cause)

  • R — Mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria (including Bacteroides, Clostridium)



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1553.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with painless enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes. Which of the following cancers is most likely to present with inguinal lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
The inguinal lymph nodes primarily drain the lower limb, perineum, external genitalia (penis or vagina), anal canal (below the pectinate line), and lower abdominal wall. Penile cancer on metastasis will drain into superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

Other options
  • Colorectal cancer drains into mesenteric and iliac lymph nodes.
  • Prostate cancer drains into internal iliac and obturator lymph nodes.
  • Testicular cancer drains into para-aortic (retroperitoneal) lymph nodes.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1444.

questions.text: Study the delayed intravenous urogram shown below and make a clinical diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Delayed intravenous pyelogram of the patient shows left hydronephrosis with absence of contrast opacification of ispilateral ureter. This is most likely to be pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction on left side. 

Other options:

  • Staghorn calculi fill the renal pelvis and calyces with radiopaque branching stones.

  • Polycystic kidney disease shows multiple cysts replacing renal parenchyma, not delayed contrast drainage pattern.

  • Putty kidney is a form of end-stage renal tuberculosis causing calcified, non-functioning kidney appearing shrunken and opaque, not delayed contrast excretion.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 1402, 1405-1406, 1410-1412.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male undergoes laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. After surgery, he complains of burning pain and numbness over the lateral aspect of the thigh, without any motor weakness. Which nerve is most likely injured during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4. Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Lateral Femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in laparoscopic hernia repair. Ilioinguinal is most common nerve injured during open hernia repair. 

  • Ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves injuries cause sensory changes in the lower abdomen, groin, or scrotum, not the lateral thigh.

  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve injury affects the cremasteric reflex and scrotal sensation.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1070.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins presents with eczematous skin changes around the affected veins. What is the CEAP classification of this patient?
questions.solution:
The Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification is a method to categorize chronic venous disorders for standardized reporting. The visible signs of chronic venous disorders are categorized as C0 to C6 depending on appearance
  • C1: Presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2 classification refers to varicose veins: subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (option A)
  • C3 refers to edema: when associated with venous reflux, it is characterized by the development of dependent ankle edema (option B)
  • C4a refers to skin pigmentation/ dermatitis/ eczema: as seen in this patient (option 3)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 974.

questions.text: A patient undergoes imaging which reveals a cystic lesion in the spleen. Which of the following is the most common type of splenic cyst?
questions.solution:
The most typical spleen cysts are hydatid cysts, which are caused by the larvae of the Echinococcus tapeworm.
Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver.
Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice Dermatoid cysts (option B), pseudocysts (option C), and lymphangiomas (option D) can also occur in the spleen but are less common.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with yellowing of the eyes and dark urine. Clinical examination suggests obstructive jaundice. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm gallstone obstruction in the biliary tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MRI
 
  • MRI provides detailed images of the biliary system, including the bile ducts, gallbladder, and liver, allowing for the visualization of any obstructions or abnormalities.
  • MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is a specific MRI technique used to evaluate the biliary system.
  • Other imaging modalities, such as ultrasound or CT scan, may also be used in the evaluation of obstructive jaundice, but MRI with MRCP is considered the most comprehensive and accurate imaging technique for this condition.
Other options:

  • Cholangiography (like ERCP) is invasive and generally reserved for therapeutic intervention.

  • CECT is less sensitive for detecting small bile duct stones and mainly used for evaluating complications.

  • X-ray is of limited use as most gallstones are radiolucent.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1495.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to persistent jaundice and pale stools since birth. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and mild scleral icterus. Laboratory investigations show elevated direct (conjugated) bilirubin and raised liver enzymes. An abdominal ultrasound shows absent or small gallbladder. A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan shows no excretion of tracer into the intestines, confirming biliary obstruction. What is the preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Kasai procedure
 
  • The preferred treatment for congenital biliary atresia is the Kasai procedure.
  • The Kasai procedure (Hepatoportoenterostomy) involves creating a surgical connection between the liver and the small intestine to bypass the obstructed bile ducts.
  • This procedure aims to restore bile flow and prevent further damage to the liver.
  • Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

  • Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy is not used in biliary atresia but for other biliary reconstructions.

  • Vitamin E supplementation is supportive for some liver conditions but has no role in resolving biliary obstruction.

* Types of Biliary Atresia: 



Kasai procedure:


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with multiple episodes of severe peptic ulcer disease that are refractory to proton pump inhibitor therapy. He also complains of chronic diarrhea and epigastric pain. Fasting serum gastrin levels are elevated. A secretin stimulation test is positive. Suspecting Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, the surgical team plans localization of the tumor. Most gastrinomas are located within the anatomical boundaries of the gastrinoma triangle. Which of the following is NOT a boundary of the gastrinoma triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein

Except for the spleen vein and inferior mesenteric vein (option D), all of the following structures bind the gastrinoma triangle.
  • The gastrinoma triangle is an anatomical region in the upper abdomen that is commonly associated with the presence of gastrinomas, tumors that produce excessive amounts of gastrin.

The gastrinoma triangle (also known as Passaro’s triangle) is the most common anatomical region where gastrinomas (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) are found.

Boundaries of the gastrinoma triangle:

  • Superiorly: Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct

  • Medially: Junction of the neck and body of the pancreas

  • Inferiorly: Second and third parts of the duodenum




Fig: Gastrinoma triangle

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1139.

questions.text: A 55-year-old uncircumcised male presents to the urology clinic with a painless growth on the glans penis, noticed over the past 3 months. He denies dysuria, bleeding, or discharge. On physical examination, retraction of the prepuce reveals a well-demarcated, cauliflower-like exophytic lesion on the glans penis. Inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a warty growth that is visible on retraction of the prepuce, representing penile carcinoma involving the glans with no inguinal lymphadenopathy on clinical examination.
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type and it most commonly originates from the glans. 
  • Lesions involving glans or distal shaft require partial penectomy with 2 cm margin.
  • This may be accompanied by bilateral ilioinguinal LN dissection in case the patient has metastatic lymph nodes.

  • CO laser ablation and topical 5-FU are used for pre-malignant or superficial penile intraepithelial neoplasia, not invasive carcinoma.

  • Podophyllin is used for condyloma acuminata (genital warts), not carcinomas.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 1553.

choices.text: Patey's surgery is done for the treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with a slowly expanding, painless swelling above the mandibular angle. Swelling moves about and has variable consistency. Regarding the swelling, all of the following are accurate, except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Has uniphasic cellular pattern
 
  • The given clinical scenario and image depict a likely case of parotid tumor (option A), likely to be a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • The parotid tail is the most common site (Option B) for parotid gland tumors to occur. It is the portion of the parotid gland that extends backward and wraps around the mandible.
  • However, the swelling in this case does not exhibit a uniphasic cellular pattern.
  • A uniphasic cellular pattern refers to the appearance of cells in the tumor, and it is not observed in this scenario.
  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation) (option C).
  • Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion, direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: During an abdominal surgery, a small accessory spleen (splenunculus) is discovered. Which of the following is the most common anatomical location for an accessory spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hilum of spleen
 
  • Splenunculi, also known as accessory spleens, are most commonly found in the hilum of the spleen. The hilum is the area where blood vessels enter and exit the spleen.
  • Splenunculi can occasionally be found in other locations, such as the greater omentum, but the hilum of the spleen is the most frequent site.
  • Other locations:
      • Splenic Hilum
      • Tail of the Pancreas
      • Gastrosplenic Ligaments
      • Lienorenal Ligaments
      • Wall of the Stomach
      • Wall of the Intestines
      • Greater Omentum
      • Mesentery
      • Pelvis or Scrotum (rarely observed)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1221.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to your clinic with a painless swelling on one side of the scrotum that has been progressively increasing in size over the past few months. He denies any trauma, fever, or urinary symptoms. On examination, the swelling is soft, non-tender, and separate from the testis. Surgical intervention is planned, and the urologist advises a Lord’s plication. Lord’s plication is done to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hydrocele
  • Lord's plication is a surgical technique used to treat hydrocele.
  • It involves the excision of excess hydrocele sac and plication (folding) of the remaining sac to reduce its size and prevent re-accumulation of fluid.
  • Surgery is rarely indicated before 2 years because a majority resolve.
  • Teenage boys may have a non-communicating hydrocele with fluid arising from the tunica vaginalis; a plication (Lord’s procedure) or excision/eversion of the tunica vaginalis (Jaboulay procedure) are needed.

 

Incorrect Options:

1. Inguinal hernia
Inguinal hernia is managed by herniotomy or hernioplasty, not Lord’s plication. The procedure for hernia involves reinforcing or repairing the inguinal canal, usually with mesh in adults.

2. Testicular cancer
The standard treatment for testicular cancer is radical inguinal orchiectomy. Lord’s plication is not used, as the focus in cancer is removal of the entire testis and cord.

4. Testicular varices (Varicocele)
Varicocele is managed by varicocelectomy, which involves ligation of the dilated veins. Lord’s plication has no role in the management of varicocele.
