Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 257.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of flank pain over the last year. He describes the pain as severe, colicky, and radiating to the groin. He has had multiple emergency visits for similar complaints. A recent non-contrast CT scan reveals a 9 mm renal calculus in the left kidney. He is scheduled for extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL). Which of the following types of renal stones is least likely to fragment with ESWL?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Calcium oxalate monohydrate
ESWL (extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy) is a non-invasive procedure used to break down kidney stones into smaller fragments using shock waves.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most challenging to break using ESWL.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones have a crystalline structure that makes them resistant to shock wave fragmentation.
  • On the other hand, calcium oxalate dihydrate, uric acid, and struvite stones are relatively easier to break using ESWL due to their composition and structure.
  • ESWL may still be attempted for calcium oxalate monohydrate stones, but alternative treatment options like ureteroscopic removal or percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) may be considered if ESWL fails to effectively break down the stones.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1471.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, presents to the outpatient clinic at 7 weeks of gestation requesting termination of pregnancy. She is healthy, with no significant past medical history and is not on any medications. Which of the following methods is used for first-trimester termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option 4. Mifepristone and misoprostol
This is the standard, evidence-based regimen for medical abortion in the first trimester (up to 10 weeks gestation). Mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) is given first to block progesterone support of the pregnancy, followed 24–48 hours later by misoprostol (a prostaglandin E1 analog) to induce uterine contractions and expulsion.

Other options:

1. Intra-amniotic hypertonic urea
This is an outdated method primarily used in the second trimester, involving instillation of urea into the amniotic sac. It is not used in the first trimester due to the small size of the gestational sac and high complication rates.

2. Extra-amniotic saline infusion
Like intra-amniotic urea, this is also a method for second-trimester termination, not first trimester. It involves the insertion of a catheter into the cervix and infusion of saline to induce abortion.

3. Oxytocin infusion
Oxytocin is more commonly used for induction of labor at term or in second-trimester pregnancy terminations. It is not effective or appropriate as a sole agent for early first-trimester abortions.

Feature First Trimester (≤ 12–14 weeks) Second Trimester (> 12–14 weeks)
Medical Abortion Mifepristone + MisoprostolMethotrexate + Misoprostol Misoprostol ± Mifepristone
Surgical Abortion Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)Suction Curettage / D&C Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
Obsolete/Not Recommended Intra/extra-amniotic instillation Sometimes used where D&E is unavailable
Other Agents Oxytocin (ineffective alone) Oxytocin (used for induction or expulsion)
Gestational Age Limit Medical abortion effective up to 10 weeks Medical options effective up to 24 weeks
Choice Based on Patient preference, gestational age, availability Provider expertise, gestational age, patient stability



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 203, 204.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, breastfeeding her 24-month-old baby, presents to the clinic complaining of heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding for the past few months. She wishes to start contraception. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she is exclusively breastfeeding. Which of the following contraceptive methods is the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive of choice in a lactating mother with heavy irregular bleeding is MALA-N. 
 
  • MALA N is a combined oral contraceptive (COC) that contains 20-30 mcg of ethinyl estradiol (EE2) and 0.15 mg of levonorgestrel. It works by inhibiting ovulation through the suppression of pituitary hormones, FSH and LH.
 
  • COCs have the lowest failure rates and are effective in managing conditions like polymenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia. However, the risk of thromboembolism is highest during the first 6 weeks postpartum (puerperal period) with COCs, and they are known to suppress lactation.
 
  • In this case, since the child is 24 months old (and complementary feeding typically begins at 6 months, meaning the child is not fully dependent on breastmilk for nutrition) and the woman is well beyond the puerperal period, MALA N can be safely used.



Other options:

  • Option 1: Norethisterone enanthate depot is an intramuscular injection given every 2 months. Though it is suitable for lactating women, it has an increased risk of irregular menstrual cycle and low BMD. So, it is not preferred in this case.
 
  • Option 2: Copper T is not recommended for this patient, as it may worsen menorrhagia and lead to anemia.
 
  • Option 3: Progestasert is a hormone-releasing IUCD that prevents sperm entry by creating a thick mucus plug at the cervix. Its use is limited in cases of heavy, unexplained bleeding.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 682.

Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 269-271, 273-277.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is present when both the Wolffian and Mullerian duct structures are absent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS)


In AIS, individuals have a 46,XY karyotype with testes producing testosterone and anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). Due to androgen receptor defects, testosterone cannot exert its effects, so Wolffian ducts regress (no male internal genitalia), while AMH causes regression of Mullerian ducts. Result: absence of both Wolffian and Mullerian structures, with female external genitalia.

Other options:

1. Anti-Mullerian hormone deficiency
AMH deficiency causes persistence of Mullerian structures (uterus, fallopian tubes) along with Wolffian structures, leading to persistent Mullerian duct syndrome in 46,XY individuals.

3. FSH receptor defect
FSH receptor defects affect ovarian follicle development in 46,XX females and do not cause absence of Wolffian or Mullerian ducts.

4. Ovotesticular syndrome
Also called true hermaphroditism, where both ovarian and testicular tissue are present, usually with both Mullerian and Wolffian structures partially developed.


Pathophysiology of AIS is given below: 





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 113, 114.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques for evaluating female fertility during a menstrual cycle can most accurately forecast when ovulation will occur?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hormonal study 
 
  • Of all the given options , hormonal study is the most reliable test for ovulation.
  • Day 21 serum progesterone levels more than 3ng/ml indicate ovulation
  • Urinary LH kits detect LH surge can detect LH levels as low as 22 mIU/ml.

Other options:

1. Basal body temperature (BBT)
Incorrect.
BBT rises after ovulation due to progesterone, so it is a retrospective indicator and cannot predict ovulation before it happens.

2. Fern test
Incorrect.
The fern test examines cervical mucus crystallization under a microscope, which changes around ovulation, but it is less precise and more subjective than hormonal tests.

3. Spinnbarkeit phenomenon
Incorrect.
Spinnbarkeit describes the stretchy, clear cervical mucus seen near ovulation, but this is a qualitative sign and less accurate compared to hormonal studies.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 194, 195.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for infertility is found to have uterine didelphys on 3D ultrasound. She is concerned about possible complications related to this condition. All of the following are potential complications of uterine didelphys except:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Transverse lie

Transverse lie is not possible in Uterine didelphys because the diameter of each cornu is less and cannot accommodate a fetus in transverse lie. 

Complications of Uterine Didelphys :
  • Repeated pregnancy loss.
  • Early labor.
  • Torn vaginal tissue between the two vaginas during labor.
  • Breech baby (facing feet first) who needs a C-section delivery.
  • Low birth weight.
  • Intrauterine growth restriction.
  • Kidney problems‌
  • Due to lack of space transverse lie is not commonly seen.


Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 422, 423.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 35, 37.

choices.text: Administration of uterotonic within 1 minutes of delivery
Immediate clamping cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has just delivered a healthy baby vaginally at a hospital. The obstetrician is preparing to manage the third stage of labor actively to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage. What action from the list below is not advised for the active management of the third stage of labour?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Immediate clamping cutting and ligation of cord

  • Delayed cord clamping (for at least 1-3 minutes) is recommended to improve neonatal iron stores and outcomes unless immediate resuscitation is required.
  • Please, also note that routine uterine massage is not a part of AMTSL anymore. It has been replaced by intermittent uterine tone assessment.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 500, 506-507.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman wants a contraceptive method that provides protection against both pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections and can be used without hormonal side effects. Identify this contraceptive method:
questions.solution:
This is the image of a female condom.
 

1. Female condom
Correct.
The female condom is a polyurethane pouch with flexible rings at both ends—one ring fits inside the vagina to hold the condom in place, and the other remains outside covering the vulva. It provides contraception and STI protection.

2. Male condom
The male condom is a sheath worn over the penis, not a pouch placed inside the vagina.

3. Cervical cap
A cervical cap is a small cup that fits tightly over the cervix and requires spermicide but does not cover the entire vaginal canal.

4. Diaphragm
The diaphragm is a dome-shaped rubber device that covers the cervix but lacks the external ring and pouch structure of the female condom.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 128.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 420.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Stein-Leventhal syndrome is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Decreased fasting insulin levels

Stein-Leventhal syndrome is another name of PCOS. 

Primary diagnostic features of human PCOS: 
1. Hyperandrogenism: 
-Acene
-Hirsutism 
- LH hypersecretion 
2. Disrupted menstrual cycles
Associated with: 
-Infertility 
-High rates of miscarriage 
3. Polycystic ovaries 
Polycystic ovaries 
Additional symptoms associated with human PCOS:
4. Metabolic disturbances 
Associated with: 
-Insulin resistance 
-Glucose intolerance 
-Obesity 
-Hyperlipidemia 
-Type 2 diabetes 
-Cardiovascular disease


Due to insulin resistance, there is increased fasting insulin levels in PCOD affected women.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman is undergoing menopause. Which of the following is the primary indication for prescribing hormone therapy (HT) in menopausal women?
questions.solution:
Hot flushes is the most common indication to start HRT.

How does Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) treat hot flushes?

Pathophysiology of Hot Flushes:

  • Hot flushes occur due to dysfunction in the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center during menopause.

  • Decline in estrogen levels narrows the thermoneutral zone.

  • Small changes in core body temperature trigger exaggerated responses like vasodilation and sweating to dissipate heat, causing hot flushes.

Role of HRT:

  • Estrogen replacement restores estrogen levels, stabilizing the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.

  • This widens the thermoneutral zone, reducing the inappropriate activation of heat-loss mechanisms.

  • Consequently, frequency and severity of hot flushes decrease.



HRT increases the risk of CA breast. 

Indications for Estrogen Replacement Therapy
Vasomotor complaints
Genitourinary symptoms
Prevention and reversal of osteoporosis
Cardiovascular protective effects
Premature ovarian failure
Hypogonadotrophic conditions
Psychologic benefits
Reduction in dermatologic effect associated with aging
Surgical removal of ovaries



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks gestation comes for a routine antenatal check-up. She asks about the additional calorie requirements during pregnancy. What is the recommended increase in daily calorie intake during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Additional 300 kcal is recommended in second trimester. 
 
  • For a pregnant woman, an additional 300 kcal per day is generally recommended in the second trimester.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics, energy needs remain similar to non-pregnant women in the first trimester but increase by 340 kcal in the second trimester and by 452 kcal in the third trimester.
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) advises an extra 300 kcal during both the second and third trimesters. Therefore, option 1 is more accurate in this context.

Pregnancy demands additional nutrients to support fetal growth and development. The National Institute of Nutrition suggests the following increases for pregnant women:

  • Protein: An extra 23 g/day compared to non-pregnant women
  • Fat: 30 g/day
  • Calcium: 1200 mg/day
  • Iron: 35 mg/day

During lactation, the ICMR recommends increasing caloric intake by 550 kcal/day for the first six months and by 400 kcal/day from 7–12 months of lactation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 167.
National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) guidelines, URL: https://www.nin.res.in/rdabook/brief_note.pdf

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who has been married for four years and has had repeated abortions visits an infertility clinic. She was discovered to have a "septate uterus" after further testing. Which procedure results in better reproductive health?
questions.solution:
• Hysteroscopic septum resection is now the procedure of choice for management of uterine septum.
  • Historically, metroplasty for a septum was performed by laparotomy via the Jones or Tompkins procedure, which involved excising a wedge of the uterine fundus containing the septum or opening the fundus and incising the septum Strassmann metroplasty is used for bicornuate uterus.

ASRM Classification of Mullerian anomalies:



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 72.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and delayed menstruation. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a suspicious adnexal mass. The diagnosis of an ovarian ectopic pregnancy is considered. Which of the following is not part of Spielberg's criteria for diagnosing ovarian ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Normal ovaries

Diagnosis of ovarian ectopic pregnancy:
The Spielberg criteria are essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy: 
a) fallopian tube at the affected site must be intact 
b) the gestational sac must occupy the normal position of the ovary 
c) the gestational sac must be connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament 
d) ovarian tissue must be located in the sac wall, which is essential for confirmation of early ovarian pregnancy

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 231.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of Physiological Vaginal Discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Cyclical
Physiological vaginal discharge varies with the menstrual cycle, increasing mid-cycle due to estrogen effects and decreasing after menstruation, thus it is cyclical.

Other options: 

1. Foul smelling
Physiological discharge is not foul smelling. A foul odor suggests infection or pathological discharge.

3. Dirty white in color
Normal discharge is usually clear to white and not dirty white or purulent, which indicates infection.

4. Adherent to vaginal wall
Physiological discharge is typically not adherent or thickly coating the vaginal walls; thick adherence suggests pathological causes like candidiasis.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 328, 329.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic concerned about her menstrual bleeding. She wants to know what is considered normal blood loss during menstruation. What is the average amount of blood loss during a normal menstrual period?
questions.solution:
Normal blood flow during menses is 30-80 ml

FIGO Classification of Uterine Bleeding:


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 67.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old lady is being evaluated for multiple, subsequent miscarriages. An ultrasound suggests a mullerian abnormality.
What is the most effective technique to verify this?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 4. Combined hysteroscopy and laparoscopy

This combination provides direct visualization of both the endometrial cavity (hysteroscopy) and the external uterine contour (laparoscopy), which is essential for accurately diagnosing and classifying Müllerian anomalies.

Other options: 

1. Transvaginal ultrasound
While useful as an initial imaging tool, it has limitations in detailed assessment of uterine contour and complex anomalies.

2. Hysterosalpingography (HSG)
HSG outlines the endometrial cavity and fallopian tube patency but cannot assess the external uterine contour, which is vital for differentiating anomalies.

3. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT)
CT is not routinely used for evaluating Müllerian anomalies due to limited soft tissue resolution compared to MRI and is associated with radiation exposure.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 37, 197.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of infertility is planned for in vitro fertilization (IVF). On evaluation, she is found to have a large, thick-walled hydrosalpinx on ultrasound. Her reproductive endocrinologist is considering surgical management to improve her chances of successful pregnancy. Which of the following procedures has been shown to significantly improve the IVF pregnancy rates in patients with large hydrosalpinges?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Salpingectomy
 
  • Tubal factors account for approximately 25% of cases of infertility, and the most severe manifestation of tubal disease is hydrosalpinx, accounting for 10-30% of tubal diseases.
 
  • Hydrosalpinx is a distension or dilatation of the fallopian tube in the presence of a distal tubal occlusion, and the most common cause is pelvic inflammatory disease. Hydrosalpinx contain embryotoxic fluid which can kill the zygote. 
 
  • Women with hydrosalpinx have lower implantation and pregnancy rates in assisted reproductive technology (ART), due to a combination of mechanical and chemical factors thought to disrupt the endometrial environment.
 
  • Current guidance is removal of the tube by salpingectomy (preferably laparoscopically) before IVF treatment.

Other options:
 

2. Salpingostomy
This procedure opens the distal tubal end but does not effectively eliminate the hydrosalpinx fluid and is associated with lower success rates compared to salpingectomy.

3. Hysteroscopic cannulation
Used for proximal tubal obstruction but not effective in treating hydrosalpinx or improving IVF outcomes.

4. Salpingography and tubal catheterization
Primarily diagnostic and therapeutic for tubal blockage but not effective for large hydrosalpinx management before IVF.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 142, 203.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and infertility. Ultrasound reveals a submucosal uterine fibroid that protrudes less than 50% into the uterine cavity. You want to classify the fibroid according to the FIGO system to guide management. According to the FIGO classification of uterine fibroids, what type is assigned to a submucosal fibroid that protrudes less than 50% into the uterine cavity?
questions.solution:
• The FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) fibroid classification system is used to describe the location of uterine fibroids. It has four types, and submucosal fibroids are assigned to Type 0 or Type 1, depending on their degree of protrusion into the uterine cavity.
 

  • Type 0: A pedunculated submucosal fibroid entirely within the endometrial cavity, with no myometrial involvement.

  • Type 1: A submucosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and <50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 2: A submucosal fibroid with <50% of its volume in the endometrial cavity and ≥50% within the myometrium.

  • Type 3: A fibroid completely within the myometrium but abutting the endometrium without extending into the endometrial cavity.

  • Type 4: A fibroid entirely within the myometrium, not in contact with the endometrium or serosa.

  • Type 5: A subserosal fibroid with ≥50% of its volume within the myometrium and <50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 6: A subserosal fibroid with <50% of its volume within the myometrium and ≥50% extending outside the uterine serosa.

  • Type 7: A pedunculated subserosal fibroid, attached to the uterus by a stalk.

  • Type 8: A fibroid located in an ectopic position (e.g., in the cervix, broad ligament, or parasitic fibroids not involving the myometrium)




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 129.

DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 226.

choices.text: Women who menstruate more than every 24 days
Women who menstruate less often than every 35 days
Women with menstrual flow for more than 5 days
Women with monthly menstrual blood loss more than 80 ml

questions.text: Exception to further evaluation is -
questions.solution:
Correct option 3:Women with menstrual flow for more than 5 days 
Rest all the options denote abnormalities of menstrual cycle and need further evaluation.

• Menorrhagia: Excessive (>80 ml) & / or prolonged menstruation (>7), at regular intervals
• Metrorrhagia - Irregular, frequent bleeding of varying amounts but not excessive
• Menometrorrhagia Prolonged or excessive bleeding at irregular intervals
• Polymenorrhea Regular bleeding at intervals of less than 21 days
• Oligomenorrhea Bleeding at intervals greater than 35 days - may be irregular
• Intermenstrual Uterine bleeding between regular cycles


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 122, 123.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and difficulty conceiving. Her blood tests reveal insulin resistance and dyslipidemia. A pelvic ultrasound shows polycystic ovaries. You counsel her regarding long-term health risks associated with her condition. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.solution:
1. Dyslipidemia
PCOS is commonly associated with lipid abnormalities, including elevated LDL and triglycerides, contributing to cardiovascular risk.

2. Endometrial carcinoma
Chronic anovulation in PCOS leads to unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.

3. Insulin resistance
Insulin resistance is a hallmark of PCOS and contributes to hyperandrogenism and metabolic syndrome.

4. Osteoporosis
PCOS is typically associated with normal or increased bone mineral density due to higher androgen levels and is not linked to osteoporosis.


Long term-consequences of PCOS:


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic seeking advice about emergency contraception after unprotected intercourse 48 hours ago. You discuss various emergency contraception options with her. Which of the following is not used as a method of emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
1. Danazol
Danazol is not used for emergency contraception. It is a synthetic androgen used mainly in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease.

2. CuT 200 B
Copper intrauterine devices like CuT 200 B are effective emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days after unprotected intercourse.

3. RU 486 (Mifepristone)
Mifepristone can be used as an emergency contraceptive and for medical termination of pregnancy.

4. High dose estrogen
High dose estrogen (often combined with progestin) was historically used as emergency contraception, though less common now due to side effects.

Concise table on types of Emergency Contraception:
 

Type of EC Description Time Frame Mechanism of Action Notes
Copper IUD (CuT 200/380A) Intrauterine device insertion after unprotected sex Within 5 days (120 hours) Prevents fertilization and implantation Most effective EC method, can be used as ongoing contraception
Levonorgestrel Pill Progestin-only pill Within 72 hours (3 days) Delays ovulation Over-the-counter in many countries
Ulipristal Acetate Selective progesterone receptor modulator Within 120 hours (5 days) Delays or inhibits ovulation More effective than levonorgestrel up to 5 days
Mifepristone (RU-486) Progesterone receptor antagonist Within 120 hours (5 days) Delays ovulation, disrupts implantation Also used for medical abortion
High-dose Estrogen/Progestin (Yuzpe regimen) Combined oral contraceptive pills in high doses Within 72 hours (3 days) Inhibits or delays ovulation Less commonly used due to side effects



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 192, 269, 270.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 131, 132.

questions.text: All stomach conditions are premalignant, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hiatus Hernia
 
  • Hiatus hernia is not considered premalignant.
  • It is a condition where a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity.
  • While hiatus hernia can cause symptoms like acid reflux, it is not directly associated with an increased risk of malignancy or cancer development in the same way that conditions like atrophic gastritis or pernicious anemia are.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 629, 630.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient presents with widening of teeth gaps, protrusion of chin, prominence of frontal bone, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance and enlargement of the feet and hand. Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of acromegaly.
Among the given options, Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition. 

Other options:
  • Option 2- Octreotide is a synthetic analogue of somatostatin. It is used as first line in treatment of acromegaly. 
  • Option 3- Cabergoline is a D2 receptor agonist. It is used in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 
  • Option 4- Bromocriptine is D2 receptor agonist used as a first line drug in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 260, 261.

choices.text: Caused by Herpes simplex-2 virus in all cases
Is also referred to as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis"

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of headache, fever, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Each episode lasts a few days and resolves spontaneously. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis during episodes shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. He has had multiple such episodes over the past year. All of the following statements are true about Mollaret's meningitis except:
questions.solution:
• Mollaret's meningitis is a rare type of meningitis that is characterized by recurrent episodes of meningitis that last for 2-5 days and then resolve spontaneously.
  • The exact cause of Mollaret's meningitis is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) in some cases.
  • However, it is important to note that not all cases of Mollaret's meningitis are caused by HSV-2. It is caused by other viruses as well like Varicella zoster virus and some non-viral etiologies also.
  • Therefore, option 1 is not completely true about Mollaret's meningitis.

Other options: 
  • Option 2 is true, as Mollaret's meningitis is a recurrent type of meningitis that is generally considered benign, as it does not cause any long-term neurological damage.
  • Option 3 is also true, as Mollaret's meningitis is also known as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis" due to its recurrent and benign nature and CSF lymphocytosis.
  • Option 4 is  true, as Mollaret's meningitis episodes usually resolve spontaneously without treatment, although antiviral drugs may be used to shorten the duration of symptoms during an episode.
 
  • Therefore, the correct option is 1, as Mollaret's meningitis is NOT ALWAYS caused by HSV-2 only.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1107.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with known HIV infection presents to the clinic. His latest CD4 count is 36 cells/mm³. He complains of fever, weight loss, and a persistent cough. Chest X-ray shows bilateral nodular opacities. Sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis is negative. On physical examination, multiple umbilicated papular lesions are noted on his face and upper chest. He has recently been started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). What is the most likely diagnosis?

 

1. Disseminated TB infection
2. Dissemination cryptococcus infection
3. Disseminated histoplasmosis
4. Disseminated molluscum contagiosum
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • Progressive disseminated histoplasmosis(PDH) is seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Common risk factors are AIDS(CD4+ T-cell count,<200/μL) extremes of age, the administration of immunosuppressive drugs(e.g., prednisone, mycophenolate, calcineurin inhibitors),and use of drugs like methotrexate, anti-TNF-a agents, and other biologic response modifiers for autoimmune disorders. It most commonly involves the lungs and bone marrow.
  • The clinical spectrum of PDH ranges from an acute, rapidly fatal course—with diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular lung infiltrates causing respiratory failure, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure—to a subacute or chronic course with a focal organ distribution.
  • Common manifestations include fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Other findings may include meningitis or focal brain lesions, ulcerations of the oral mucosa, gastrointestinal ulcerations and bleeding, and adrenal insufficiency. Prompt recognition of this devastating illness is of paramount importance in patients with severe manifestations or with underlying immunosuppression, especially that due to AIDS.

Fig: Intracellular yeasts (arrows) of H. capsulatum in a liver biopsy specimen (hematoxylin and eosin stain) from a patient who developed progressive disseminated histoplasmosis.

Other options:
 

  • Disseminated tuberculosis: Usually presents with constitutional symptoms and lung involvement but CBNAAT negative sputum and characteristic skin lesions are uncommon.

  • Disseminated cryptococcal infection: Usually presents with meningitis; cutaneous lesions are rare and look different.

  • Disseminated molluscum contagiosum: Causes umbilicated papules but typically no lung involvement or nodular opacities.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1658.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue. An ECG strip (shown below) is obtained. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Ventricular premature complex.

The ECG strip displays a premature ventricular beat (VPC), originating from the ventricles.
VPCs are frequent and typically not harmful, but they may indicate underlying heart conditions like heart disease or cardiomyopathy.

Criteria of ECG for ventricular premature complex (VPC):
  • Premature beat that originates in the ventricles.
  • QRS complex is wider than 0.12 seconds.
  • There is no P wave preceding the QRS complex.
  • The QRS complex is usually bizarre in appearance.
  • The T wave is usually inverted.
  • The VPC may be followed by a compensatory pause


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1915-1917.

questions.text: A patient with palpitations is brought to the emergency room. The following image can be seen on the ECG recording. What medication is preferred to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lignocaine
 
  • The ECG shows a regular rhythm with a wide QRS complex, indicating ventricular tachycardia (VT).
  • VT is a serious arrhythmia requiring immediate treatment.
  • In a hemodynamically stable patient amiodarone, lidocaine, and procainamide can be used to treat the condition
  • Preferred medication: Lignocaine
  • In hemodynamically unstable patients, electrical cardioversion is done.

Other options:

  • Procainamide: This is a class IA antiarrhythmic used for VT but generally considered second-line after lidocaine or amiodarone, especially in the acute setting.

  • Beryllium: This is a toxic metal, not used as a medication.

  • Moricizine: This is a class IC antiarrhythmic, rarely used now due to safety concerns and not first-line for VT.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1913.

questions.text: A newborn delivered vaginally presents with a swelling on the scalp soon after birth. The swelling is soft, diffuse, and seems to extend across the cranial sutures. Which of the following types of extracranial hemorrhage is characterized by bleeding that crosses the cranial sutures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Subgaleal hemorrhage
 
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can occur in hereditary coagulopathies and is associated with skull fractures.
  • Subgaleal hemorrhages can be large and can cross sutures.
  • Cephalohematoma and caput succedaneum: both do not cross sutures.






Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressively worsening tremors in his right hand for the past 8 months. He also reports stiffness in his limbs and slow movements that have started interfering with his daily activities. There is no history of recent infections or drug use. On examination, you note a resting tremor, cogwheel rigidity, and bradykinesia. His gait is slow and shuffling. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to start for managing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Parkinson's disease. Among the given options, selegiline is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. 
 
  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine in the brain, thus helping to alleviate symptoms of Parkinson's disease, particularly tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Other options:
 

  • Haloperidol: This is an antipsychotic medication, but it can worsen the symptoms of Parkinson's disease by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain. It is not used to treat Parkinson’s and may actually induce drug-induced parkinsonism.

  • Clozapine: This is an atypical antipsychotic that has a lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects (such as parkinsonism) compared to other antipsychotics. However, it is primarily used for schizophrenia and not for treating Parkinson’s disease.

  • Donepezil: This is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used for Alzheimer's disease. It increases acetylcholine levels but does not directly address the dopamine deficiency in Parkinson’s disease and would not be an appropriate treatment for this condition.

Thus, Selegiline is the correct choice for treating Parkinsonian symptoms in this case.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 458, 459, 467, 468.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive movement difficulties, including dystonia, rigidity, and tremors. MRI of the brain reveals neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the basal ganglia. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hallervorden-Spatz Disease
 
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease caused by PANK2 gene mutation is the most common form of Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation (NBIA) and is manifested as a combination of dystonia (hyperkinetic), parkinsonism (hypokinetic), and spasticity.
  • T2W-MRI shows the characteristic eye of the tiger sign due to iron accumulation in globus pallidus.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3409.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a severe throbbing headache localized to the left side. Prior to the headache, she experienced nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. She wants immediate relief from her symptoms. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate to provide rapid symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of classical migraine. Among the given options, Sumatriptan will be the drug of choice to terminate an acute attack.

It acts as an agonist at 5HTIB and 5HT1D receptors. 
 
  • Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT) receptor agonist and is commonly used to abort or relieve acute migraine attacks. It works by constricting blood vessels and inhibiting the release of substances that contribute to the migraine pain. It provides rapid relief and is effective for the symptoms described (headache, nausea, photophobia, etc.).

Other options:
 

  • Propranolol: This is a beta-blocker and is commonly used as a prophylactic treatment for migraines, not for acute relief. It helps prevent future migraine attacks but does not provide immediate relief during an active episode.

  • Topiramate: This is an anticonvulsant medication that is used prophylactically to reduce the frequency of migraines. It is not effective for providing immediate relief during an acute migraine attack.

  • Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine with anti-serotonergic properties. While it has some off-label use for migraine prevention in certain cases, it is not a first-line treatment for acute relief of migraines.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3357, 3359, 3361, 3363.

questions.text: What is Brock's Syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis
 
  • Brock's syndrome, also known as Middle Lobe Syndrome, is a condition that affects the middle lobe of the lungs (other lobes are not affected).
  • It is characterized by the presence of bronchiectasis, which is a permanent dilation of the bronchi. This can lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, sputum production, and recurrent respiratory infections.

Reference: Kunal, Shekhar et al. “Middle lobe syndrome: an intriguing presentation of tracheobronchial amyloidosis.” BMJ case reports vol. 2017 bcr2017219480. 22 May. 2017, doi:10.1136/bcr-2017-219480. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5753675/

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with Bronchiectasis Sicca?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberculosis 
 

Bronchiectasis Sicca, also known as dry bronchiectasis, is a form of bronchiectasis characterized by:

  • Minimal sputum production

  • Recurrent hemoptysis

  • Often seen in the upper lobes

  • Frequently linked with healed pulmonary tuberculosis (TB)

Unlike other forms of bronchiectasis (which present with productive cough and recurrent infections), Bronchiectasis Sicca tends to be dry and hemoptysis-dominant. It is most commonly associated with post-tuberculous scarring and fibrosis.

Other options:
 

  • Pertussis → Typically causes acute bronchitis, not specifically associated with bronchiectasis sicca.

  • Cystic fibrosis → Causes diffuse, mucus-filled bronchiectasis, not the dry variant.

  • Kartagener syndrome → Causes generalized ciliary dysfunction with wet, productive bronchiectasis and situs inversus.




Reference: Butler, Marcus W., and Michael P. Keane. “Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis.” Infectious Diseases(2017): 243–250.e2. doi:10.1016/B978-0-7020-6285-8.00027-7. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7150028/

questions.text: Which of the following conditions presents with an elevated aPTT with a normal PT?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: SLE.
 
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the blood.
  • In SLE, the aPTT is often prolonged due to the presence of lupus anticoagulant, which is an antiphospholipid antibody that interferes with the clotting process and leads to a tendency for increased bleeding. 
  • However, the PT remains normal because lupus anticoagulant does not affect the extrinsic pathway, which is measured by PT.

  • Cirrhosis → Prolonged PT and aPTT (due to decreased synthesis of coagulation factors). 
  • SVC obstruction → Does not cause aPTT/PT abnormalities; it leads to venous congestion. 
  • SLE → Lupus anticoagulant (LA) prolongs aPTT due to interference with phospholipid-dependent coagulation tests. However, paradoxically, LA is associated with thrombosis rather than bleeding. 
  • Hypothyroidism → Can cause mildly prolonged aPTT due to decreased factor production, but it is not a primary cause of isolated aPTT prolongation. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 456, 2741, 2749.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with the sudden onset of a severe headache described as the "worst headache of her life." She also complains of neck stiffness, photophobia, and nausea. There is no history of trauma or recent illness. On examination, she appears distressed, and there is mild nuchal rigidity. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SAH , as in the CT scan hemorrhage is seen in the fissures that is the subarachnoid space. 
 

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically presents with:

    • Sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache

    • Neck stiffness, photophobia

    • No trauma history in cases due to aneurysmal rupture

    • CT brain shows blood in subarachnoid spaces (e.g., cisterns, fissures)

  • Meningitis can also present with neck stiffness but has gradual onset and fever.

  • Hemorrhagic stroke is sudden but usually presents with focal neurological deficits and bleeding into brain parenchyma, not subarachnoid space.

  • Subdural hematoma is typically due to trauma and presents more insidiously, especially in older adults.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3355.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient department 3 days after being discharged from the emergency department following a road traffic accident (RTA). A CT scan at the time of injury revealed a subdural hematoma (SDH). He now complains of persistent headache and blurred vision. On examination, his vital signs are stable, and neurologic exam shows no focal deficits. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral papilledema. What is the most likely cause of his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Raised ICT
  • Papilledema is a swelling of the optic disc, caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which is the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) inside the skull.
  • In the case, the patient has a history of RTA, and a CT scan has revealed an SDH. 
  • SDH is a collection of blood between the dura mater, meninges, and the arachnoid mater. This collection of blood can increase ICP, which can lead to papilledema.

Other options : 
  • Meningitis, Optic neuritis, and Glaucoma are less likely causes, as they are not directly related to the history of RTA and SDH.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 323-325.

questions.text: What is the cause of the following murmur?
questions.solution:
The given image is representative of the phonocardiogram (PCG) tracing obtained in a patient. The murmur represented is a holosystolic murmur i.e. lying between the first and second heart sounds, with equal intensities of S1 and S2.
The murmur of mitral regurgitation is often described as a holosystolic, high-pitched, “blowing murmur” which is loudest at the apex and radiates towards the axilla. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1997.

questions.text: ECG of a 48 year old man is shown below. Which of the following can lead to the ECG changes shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient reveals tall, symmetrically peaked T waves. Based on the options, the patient is likely being managed with antihypertensives.
The finding of peaked/ tall T waves can be due to hyperkalemia, and in this patient it is likely to be medication-induced, the likely culprit being spironolactone.
Spironolactone is a potassium Sparing Diuretic. It is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of kidneys. as a result, Spironolactone Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

Mnemonic for remembering causes of Tall 'T' Waves:
HYPER K TALLS

Letter Cause Explanation
H Hyperkalemia Most common cause; classic tall, peaked T waves
Y Young (early MI) Tall T waves may appear in early stages of STEMI
P Pericarditis May cause diffuse tall T waves in early phase
E Early repolarization Normal variant, especially in young healthy adults
R Reperfusion after MI Tall T waves due to sudden blood flow restoration
K Kidney failure Secondary to hyperkalemia and metabolic derangement
T Thyrotoxicosis Causes sympathetic overactivity and ECG changes
A Acidosis (Metabolic) Seen in conditions like DKA—associated with hyperkalemia
L Left ventricular overload Strain patterns may cause tall T waves
L LBBB (Left Bundle Branch Block) Alters ventricular depolarization and repolarization
S Strenuous exercise Can transiently raise T wave height, especially in trained athletes



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 348.

questions.text: A 78-year old lady was brought to the OPD with complaints of progressive difficulty in daily activities for 6 months, convulsions and visual hallucinations. The patient is reported to stare calmly and continuously at the sky. The autopsy of the patient revealed Lewy bodies. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Lewy body disease, which is the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia, after Alzheimer’s disease.
  • One may have even considered PDD (i.e. Parkinson disease dementia) a suitable answer as it is part of the spectrum of Lewy body disease.
  • Based on this premise, and exclusion of other options, Parkinson's disease (PD) has been chosen as the single-best answer.
  • Please note PDD and PD are distinct conditions but approximately 10% of patients with PD develop PDD per year, with the majority of PD patients developing PDD over time.
Diagnosis: 
  • The key neuropathologic feature in LBD is the presence of Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites throughout specific brainstem nuclei, substantia nigra, amygdala, cingulate gyrus, and, ultimately, the neocortex.
  • Lewy bodies are intraneuronal cytoplasmic inclusions that stain with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) and ubiquitin but are now identified with antibodies to the presynaptic protein α-synuclein.
  • Lewy bodies are composed of straight neurofilaments 7–20 nm long with surrounding amorphous material and contain epitopes recognized by antibodies against phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated neurofilament proteins, ubiquitin, and α-synuclein.
  • The presence of α-synuclein aggregates in neurons and glia in PDD and DLB molecularly classifies these diseases as synucleinopathies.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3385.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the clinic with palpitations, chest discomfort, and fatigue. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border. Jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform analysis reveals prominent 'a' waves. There are no signs of pulmonary edema or cyanosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has tricuspid stenosis.
 

  • Mid-diastolic murmur: Suggestive of valvular stenosis — either mitral or tricuspid.

  • Location of murmur: TS is best heard at the left lower sternal border, especially with inspiration (Carvallo’s sign).

  • Large 'a' waves on JVP: Indicates difficulty in right atrial emptying into the right ventricle, characteristic of tricuspid stenosis.

  • Symptoms: Palpitations and fatigue can result from decreased cardiac output and right atrial enlargement.




Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1817.

questions.text:
A 50-year old man who is a chronic smoker has a cough with hemoptysis. He complains of shooting pain in the right arm. The patient is noted to have ptosis too. Chest X-Ray findings are as shown. What is the diagnosis?

1. SVC syndrome
2. Pancoast tumor
3. Thyroid cancer
4. Aspergilloma
questions.solution:
A chronic smoker with hemoptysis, ptosis, and unilateral pain in the arm with CXR revealing a right upper lobe mass likely has a Pancoast tumor/ superior sulcus tumor. 
  • The central or endobronchial growth of the tumor is responsible for the cough and hemoptysis and suggests a diagnosis of lung cancer.
  • Superior sulcus tumors represent a distinctive subset of stage III disease. These tumors arise in the apex of the lung and may invade the second and third ribs, the brachial plexus, the subclavian vessels, the stellate ganglion, and adjacent vertebral bodies.
  • They also may be associated with Pancoast syndrome, characterized by pain that may arise in the shoulder or chest wall or radiate to the neck. Pain characteristically radiates to the ulnar surface of the hand.
  • Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) due to invasion of the paravertebral sympathetic chain may be present as well. Patients with these tumors should undergo the same staging procedures as all patients with stage II and III NSCLC.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy or combined chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery is reserved for those without N2 involvement.

Other options:

  • SVC syndrome: Usually presents with facial swelling, cyanosis, and distended neck veins.

  • Thyroid cancer: Does not typically cause apical lung mass or Horner’s syndrome.

  • Aspergilloma: Usually presents as a fungus ball in pre-existing lung cavities, not with brachial plexus symptoms or Horner’s syndrome.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: In a study among two groups of people working in an aniline dye factory, bladder cancer among factory workers is compared to bladder  cancer among office workers for the last 20 years. The past work records are obtained from the offices. What type of study is performed?
questions.solution:
A retrospective cohort study (or "historical" cohort study) is one in which the outcomes have all occurred before the start of the investigation.

  • The investigator goes back in time, sometimes 10 to 30 years, to select his study groups from existing records of past employment, medical or other records and traces them forward through time, from a past date fixed on the records, usually up to the present.
  • This type of study is known by a variety of names : retrospective cohort study, "historical" cohort study, prospective study in retrospect and non-concurrent prospective study.
  • Study time is often of shorter duration because predictor measurements have already been made and documented. In addition, such studies can be less costly and time-consuming than prospective cohort studies. 


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 84.

choices.text: Achieve comparability between study and control groups

questions.text: A 45-year-old man enrolls in a clinical trial comparing a new medication to a placebo for treating hypertension. It is supposed to be a double-blind clinical study. Double blinding in clinical studies is done for what reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Avoid observer and subject bias

Blinding is done to reduce and prevent bias.
  • Single – subject is blind.
  • Double – subject and observer both are blind.
  • Triple – subject, observer, analyser are blind.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended method for the safe disposal of cytotoxic and outdated medications?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Landfill.
  • Cytotoxic medications and outdated drugs are considered hazardous pharmaceutical waste.
  • The preferred method for disposing of such waste is through landfill disposal in specifically designated hazardous waste disposal sites.
  • Proper disposal of pharmaceutical waste is crucial to prevent environmental contamination and potential harm to human health.
  • Dumping is not an acceptable method of disposing of hazardous waste.
  • Autoclaving and burning are effective methods of destroying cytotoxic and outdated medications, but they are not practical for large quantities of waste.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text: Mass chemoprophylaxis (mass drug administration) is an important public health strategy used to control or eliminate certain infectious diseases in endemic areas. For which of the following diseases is mass chemoprophylaxis NOT routinely recommended as a control strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Leprosy
 

  • Yaws: Mass treatment with single-dose azithromycin is recommended to interrupt transmission in endemic communities as part of the WHO yaws eradication strategy.

  • Trachoma: Mass administration of azithromycin is a key component of the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement) for trachoma control.

  • Lymphatic filariasis: Mass drug administration with diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and albendazole or ivermectin is used to interrupt transmission in endemic areas.

  • Leprosy: Although contact prophylaxis with single-dose rifampicin is recommended for high-risk contacts, mass chemoprophylaxis for entire communities is not routinely practiced due to the disease's long incubation period, low infectivity, and risk of drug resistance.



THE FOLLOWING TABLE ESTIMATES THE DISEASES FOR WHICH CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS IS USED AND THE DRUGS USED FOR THE RESPECTIVE DISEASES :-





Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: The resurgence of malaria is caused by all of the following factors, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Drug resistance in host

3 MOST IMPORTANT FACTORS RESULTING IN RESURGENCE OF MALARIA ARE:-
  • Drug resistance in parasite
  • Drug resistance in vectors
  • Antigenic variation in parasite – This invades the immune system thereby leading to development of persistent infections.
Optionwise analysis:

  • Drug resistance in the malaria parasite (e.g., chloroquine resistance) is a major cause of treatment failure and malaria resurgence.

  • Insecticide resistance in mosquito vectors reduces the effectiveness of vector control measures like insecticide-treated nets and indoor spraying.

  • Antigenic variation in the parasite allows immune evasion, complicating immunity and vaccine development.

  • However, drug resistance does not occur in the human host; resistance refers to the parasite or vector, not the human.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 311.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following traits apply to health indicators.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Affordability

Health indicators measure different aspects of health of a population.
Examples include – life expectancy, infant mortality, disability rates

Characteristics of health indicators :
  • Valid
  • Reliable
  • Sensitive
  • Specific
  • Feasible
  • Relevant

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 24.

questions.text: Malaria vaccine primarily targets which specific malaria parasite antigen?
questions.solution:
• The RTS,S malaria vaccine is designed to induce immunity against the circumsporozoite protein (CSP), which is expressed on the surface of Plasmodium falciparum sporozoites.

  • This protein is critical for the parasite’s invasion of liver cells during the early stage of infection.

  • The vaccine includes parts of the CSP fused with a hepatitis B surface antigen to improve immunogenicity.

  • Gametocyte protein is involved in the sexual stages but is not targeted by RTS,S.

  • Polysaccharide sheath and lipoprotein envelope are not relevant to the malaria vaccine design.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which of the following Arboviral diseases is not found in India?
questions.solution:
Arboviral diseases are viral infections transmitted by arthropods like mosquitoes and sandflies. Several arboviral infections occur worldwide, but their distribution depends on the presence of specific vectors and ecological conditions.

  • Dengue fever:
    Caused by dengue virus, transmitted mainly by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. It is highly endemic in India with frequent outbreaks, especially during and after the monsoon season due to increased mosquito breeding. Common clinical features include high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, rash, and muscle/joint pain.

  • West Nile Fever:
    Caused by West Nile virus, transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. It is present sporadically in India and has caused localized outbreaks. Most infections are asymptomatic, but some may develop fever, rash, or neurological symptoms.

  • Sandfly Fever:
    Transmitted by Phlebotomus sandflies, this disease is reported in some parts of India, especially in rural or desert areas. It typically causes a sudden onset of fever, headache, malaise, and muscle pain, often self-limiting.

  • Yellow Fever:
    A flavivirus transmitted by Aedes and Haemagogus mosquitoes, yellow fever is endemic in tropical regions of Africa and South America but is not present in India. India has no indigenous transmission or outbreaks of yellow fever. The country enforces strict vaccination requirements for travelers arriving from yellow fever-endemic countries to prevent introduction.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 327.

choices.text: Intervention based on assessment of community needs

questions.text: Which of the following best exemplifies the highest level of community involvement?
questions.solution:
The highest level of community involvement is when the community itself is actively involved in the planning of interventions.
  • This level of participation indicates that the community members are not just recipients of services or passive participants but are actively engaged in identifying issues, deciding on the interventions, and planning how to implement these interventions.
  • This represents a high degree of ownership, empowerment, and sustainability of the initiatives.
Intervention based on assessment of community needs (Option 2) typically involves external agents assessing the needs and designing interventions accordingly, which may or may not fully involve the community in the decision-making process.

Provision of resources by community (Option 3) shows a significant level of involvement, but it focuses on the community contributing resources rather than being involved in planning.

Community supports and cooperates with workers (Option 4) is a lower level of involvement, where the community cooperates with interventions designed and implemented by others but does not lead or plan them.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't constitute a necessary part of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Primary health care is based on principles such as
  • accessibility,
  • community participation,
  • health promotion, and
  • the provision of essential services like immunization, health education, and essential drugs.


While cost-effectiveness is important in healthcare delivery, it is not specifically defined as a fundamental component of primary healthcare.
The other options (provision of essential drugs, immunization, and health education) are core elements of primary healthcare as outlined by the Alma-Ata Declaration.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which of the following encapsulates a recent medical trend?
questions.solution:
Community participation has become a prominent trend in modern healthcare, emphasizing the involvement of the community in health planning, decision-making, and intervention strategies.
  • This trend reflects a shift towards empowering communities to take an active role in their health, ensuring that healthcare interventions are more effective, sustainable, and culturally appropriate.
  • While qualitative inquiry, equitable distribution, and primary healthcare are all important concepts, community participation represents a specific trend in the evolving landscape of public health.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which polio virus strains are included in the bivalent oral polio vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 1 & 3
 
  • OPV initially consisted of a mixture of live attenuated poliovirus strains of each of the three serotypes. 
  • OPV used in India contained, Type 1 virus 10 lakh, Type 2 virus 2 lakh and Type 3 virus 3 lakh TC ID50 per dose (0.5 ml). 
  • Trivalent vaccine has now been replaced by bivalent OPV, by removing the type 2 component from immunisation programmes (OPV switch) ad Type 2 virus is eliminated. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 241.

questions.text: According to the SDGs, the goal for MMR is to reach maternal mortality rates of:
questions.solution:
• The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) is an agenda of global goals created by the United Nations in 2015 that outlines a plan of action for countries, international organizations and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to end poverty, protect the environment, and promote peace and prosperity through sustainable development.
  • As part of the SDG 2030, the target for Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is to achieve maternal deaths of no more than 70 per 100,000 live births by 2030. This means that for every 100,000 live births, there should be 70 or fewer maternal deaths.
  • This goal is part of the UN's aim to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio by at least three quarters between 2015 and 2030. This target will help to reduce maternal mortality and ensure better access to healthcare for mothers around the world.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 825.

choices.text: Size of bars in the cross in equal horizontally and vertically
Can be used by personnel of United Nations Organizations (UNO)
Misuse of emblem is punishable offense under Indian Law

questions.text: Everything regarding the "Red Cross" insignia is accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Can be used by personnel of United Nations Organizations (UNO)
 
  • The Red Cross insignia, consisting of a red cross on a white background, is an internationally recognized symbol of protection and neutrality for medical and humanitarian personnel during armed conflicts and disasters.
  • The International Committee of the Red Cross is based out of Geneva, Switzerland.
  • The UNO is not a part of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, so its personnel are not authorized to use the Red Cross emblem.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 1032.

questions.text: In the Indian National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), the Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) plays a crucial role in community health. At which level of the healthcare system is the ASHA primarily posted to act as a link between the community and health services?
questions.solution:
Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a community health worker instituted by the government of India as part of the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • ASHA workers are posted at the village level to act as a bridge between the community and the healthcare system, ensuring that health services are accessible to the rural population.
  • Their role includes promoting healthy behaviors, ensuring immunization, assisting with healthcare access, and promoting institutional deliveries.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: Select the most ionizing wave
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Gamma rays
 
  • It is a trick question asking "wave".
  • Alpha is more ionizing but its a particle.
  • Amongst the given options, Gamma rays is the most ionizing "wave" because it has the maximum frequency. 
Electromagnetic spectrum of various rays are given below: 





Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 5, 11, 98.

questions.text: A known case of Rheumatoid arthritis attended ophthalmology OPD with the complaints as shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows scleral thinning with protusion of uveal tissue through it. In a patient of rheumatoid arthritis, this diagnosis goes in favor of Scleromalacia perforans. 
 

Scleromalacia Perforans is a severe form of scleritis that occurs primarily in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by painless thinning and perforation of the sclera, typically in the inferior quadrant of the eye.

Pathophysiology: Immune-mediated inflammation leads to thinning and weakening of the sclera, without significant initial inflammation.

Clinical Features:
  • Asymptomatic in early stages.
  • Gradual thinning of the sclera, which may eventually lead to perforation.
  • Unlike typical scleritis, pain and redness may be minimal or absent in advanced stages.
Diagnosis: Based on clinical examination, with potential imaging (e.g., ultrasound, OCT) to assess scleral thinning and perforations.

Treatment: Primarily involves managing the underlying rheumatoid arthritis with immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, methotrexate, biologics). Surgical repair may be needed for scleral perforations.

Prognosis: Early detection and treatment can slow progression, but if untreated, it may lead to severe complications, including loss of the eye.

Scleromalacia perforans is a sight-threatening complication of rheumatoid arthritis that requires prompt and aggressive management to prevent irreversible damage.

Other options:

  • Ciliary staphyloma is an outpouching of the weakened sclera near the limbus with uveal tissue protrusion, often associated with trauma or inflammation.

  • Coloboma is a congenital defect involving missing ocular tissue, usually inferonasal.

  • Equatorial staphyloma occurs at the equator of the eyeball and is usually related to high myopia or trauma.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 97, 147-149, 180, 183, 257, 398.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with sudden, painless, profound vision loss in one eye. Fundoscopy reveals a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is suspected. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with CRAO?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Orbital mucormycosis > 2. Diabetic Retinopathy
 
  • Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is known to be associated with Orbital mucormycosis.
  • CRAO is sight-threatening emergency caused by a sudden blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to ischemia of the retina. It is commonly associated with embolism, infections and vasculitis. Inflammation in the form of vasculitis or infection (e.g., varicella or mucor infection), optic neuritis, or even orbital disease (e.g., mucormycosis) may cause central retinal artery obstruction.
  • Orbital mucormycosis is a rare but serious fungal infection caused by the rhizopus species.
  • Rhizopus is knownn be to be angio-invasive- can lead to the invasion of blood vessels, including the central retinal artery, resulting in CRAO and subsequent loss of blood supply to the retina 
Other risk factors for CRAO include:
  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma
Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is known to be associated with CRVO but not CRAO. Diabetic Retinopathy is an MICRO-angiopathy - hence will affect small vessels and does NOT lead to occlusion in bigger vessel like Central retinal artery. Infection and embolus are more common - hence, Orbital mucormycosis is a better answer.
 

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 520.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmologist by his parents because they noticed a whitish reflex in the pupil (leukocoria) in photographs taken with flash. The child had progressive vision loss and eventually underwent enucleation of the affected eye. Histopathological examination of the excised tissue revealed the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
questions.solution:
• Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

  • Presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex), strabismus, vision loss, and sometimes proptosis.

  • Histology hallmark:
    → Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are circular arrangements of tumor cells around a central lumen — highly specific for retinoblastoma.

  • Treatment: Enucleation is often required in advanced or unilateral cases.

Image shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes—arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent “lumen”.


 

Other options: 
 

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma: Malignant soft tissue tumor, may involve orbit but does not show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

  • Medulloblastoma: A cerebellar tumor, seen in the posterior fossa of children; shows Homer Wright rosettes, not Flexner-Wintersteiner.

  • Astrocytoma: Brain tumor of glial origin; not associated with leukocoria or these rosettes.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1325.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders typically does NOT show a cherry red spot on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: None.

Cherry red spot can be seen in all the diseases given above.

Niemann Pick Disease:
  • Niemann-Pick disease is a group of inherited metabolic disorders characterized by the abnormal accumulation of lipids in cells throughout the body.
  • In Niemann-Pick disease, a cherry red patch can be observed on the retina of the eye.

GM1 gangliosidosis:
  • GM1 gangliosidosis is a rare genetic disorder that affects the CNS.
  • In GM1 gangliosidosis, a cherry red spot can be seen on the macula of the retina.

Tay-Sachs disease:
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence of a specific enzyme, resulting in the accumulation of certain fats in the brain and nerve cells.
  • In Tay-Sachs disease, a cherry red spot can be observed on the macula of the retina.

 

Mnemonic: "CRASH the Cherry"

 

C – Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)
R – Retinal storage diseases (esp. Tay-Sachs, Niemann-Pick, GM1 Gangliosidosis)
A – A-Type GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs)
S – Sphingomyelinase deficiency (Niemann-Pick)
H – Hurler Syndrome/Hallevorden Spatz disease


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 521.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with gradual, painless, progressive loss of vision over the past year. She does not report redness, trauma, or discharge. She has difficulty seeing in bright light and often notices glare while driving at night. Fundus is difficult to visualize due to lens opacity. Slit lamp examination confirms the diagnosis. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for this patient?

1. Immature senile cataract: phacoemulsification with IOL
2. Rosette cataract: restrict glucose intake
3. Sunflower cataract: lens extraction
4. Zonular cataract: lensectomy
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Immature senile cataract

An elderly patient with painless, progressive, gradual diminution of vision is being examined. The pupil is dilated to allow examination of the lens, which reveals wedge-shaped opacifications with an iris shadow.

Triangular spokes of opacity with their apices towards the center are indicative of a cuneiform senile cataract. 

Management: The preferred surgical technique is phacoemulsification (ultrasonic emulsification of lens) with intraocular lens (IOL) implantation, which restores vision effectively.

Other options: 

  • Rosette cataract: Seen in trauma or diabetes; glucose restriction is not a definitive treatment.

  • Sunflower cataract: Associated with Wilson's disease (copper deposition); managed primarily by treating Wilson’s disease, not by routine lens extraction.

  • Zonular cataract: Seen in congenital conditions like Down syndrome; treated with lensectomy in children, not elderly.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 194.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the outpatient department by his parents with complaints of progressive vision loss, excessive tearing (epiphora), and photophobia. What is the diagnosis of this child?

1. Congenital glaucoma
2. Mucopolysaccharidosis
3. Retinoblastoma
4. Congenital cataract
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Congenital glaucoma

The child with progressive vision loss, lacrimation, photophobia, and an enlarged, hazy cornea with a frosted-glass appearance/ ground glass appearance as shown in the image has congenital glaucoma.
 

Classic Triad:

  • Epiphora (excessive tearing)

  • Photophobia

  • Blepharospasm (involuntary eye closure)



The examination should include following:
l. Measurement of/OP preferably with hand held Perkin's applanation tonometer or Tonopen should be done since scleral rigidity is very low in children. TOP measurement und e r GA is unpredictably altered.

2. Measurement of corneal diameter by callipers.
3. Slit-lamp examination should be carried out with portable slit-lamp.
4. Ophthalmoscopy to evaluate optic disc.
5. Gonioscopic examination of angle of anterior chamber reveals trabeculo-dysgenesis with either flat or concave iris insertion as described in pathogenesis. Gonioscopy in performed under general anaesthesia using Koeppe's lens for direct visualisation of the angle structures.


Other options: 

  • Mucopolysaccharidosis: Cloudy cornea may be seen, but is associated with developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and coarsened facial features.

  • Retinoblastoma: Typically presents with leukocoria (white reflex), not photophobia or tearing.

  • Congenital cataract: Causes a white pupillary reflex, not corneal haziness or tearing.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 234.

questions.text:
Identify the type of refractive error?

 
1. Myopia
2. Hypermetropia
3. Presbyopia
4. Astigmatism
questions.solution:
Answer: (4). Astigmatism

This image represents the configuration of rays refracted through a toric surface and is called Sturm’s conoid.


Sturm’s Conoid is a concept used to understand astigmatism — a refractive error where the eye has different curvatures in different meridians (like a football shape instead of a basketball). This causes light to focus at two different points instead of one, forming two line foci (not a single point focus), creating a conoid of Sturm between them.

  • The Interval of Sturm is the distance between the two line foci, B & F..

  • In regular astigmatism, the principal meridians are at 90° to each other.

  • The goal of cylindrical lenses is to collapse this interval so light focuses at one point.


The horizontal and vertical rays of light converge at different points on the retina due to the irregular shape of the cornea or lens. This condition is known as astigmatism.

Key Diagnostic Clue from Image:
 

  • Two focal lines → classic of astigmatism.

  • Not seen in spherical errors like myopia or hyperopia, where there's a single focal point.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No- 84.
